The movement when traversing is some of the best I have seen in any video game, especially once you start getting research completed that assists with it and opens new options, and the factory building is fantastic, the most satisfying I have ever done when you finally get it working right. Its a shame though, how the game feels like it discourages actually exploring or trying new bases in the same game. If you want to find a new place, it can take ages to reach a new biome, and if your new location is not perfect, or set up like the areas when you first start out, it can be just an absolute exercise in frustration to get a new location set up. Not to mention you need to dismantle your main building, and the primary progression building as well if you want to relocate as you can only have one. This probably will not effect many people, but as someone who likes to reset there base without just starting a new game, it is quite disappointing

Early game is great, and true to what an automation game should be... but the farther in you get, the less fun, less intuitive, and more tedious it gets. While complication is a necessary part of the progress with this genre of game, Satisfactory conflates tedium and complication, ultimately falling on its ass without the statistical tools that we've come to expect in this sort of factory builder. 

QOL is decidedly lacking as well, a prime example of which is the level restricted access to blueprinting. Another good example of poor QOL is that everytime you open a number of menus (you will do this a lot) it plays a smoke-detectoresque beep/chirp the volume of which is controlled by main volume. This is a particularly poignant example of poor QOL because so many other sounds have separate sound control sliders, and the one set of sounds that doesn't is the single one that I would have liked to have muted.

Ultimately I must give this game an Unsatisfactory/10.

[h1]You will need to use your brain[/h1]
I want to preface this review by saying [b]this is not a game to turn your brain off to.[/b] You will think and puzzle over how you want to accomplish the goals set before you.

[h1]An amazing escape[/h1]
That being said: [b]Satisfactory is not stressful in the slightest,[/b] If you do start to feel overwhelmed by the factory, you can explore a absolutely massive map and collect materials to unwind.

[h1]Easy to learn, hard to master[/h1]
The game is super easy to get into and understand, but if you aren't careful, larger builds can become messy and hard to work with. [b]Don't get discouraged[/b] if you can't make beautiful, efficient factories right off the bat. I'm 257 hours in and just now starting to get the hang of organizing my factories.

TL:DR
- Satisfactory is an amazing game for people who enjoy thinking and creating. Programmers, math nerds, engineers, and builders will all find themselves at home. 
- There is a high skill ceiling, but the game is easy to start and enjoyable to learn.
- The map is beautiful and huge so there is plenty of room to explore when you aren't building your factories.

I tried really hard to like this game. Unfortunately, I found that very little time was spent solving logistic puzzles and a great deal of time was spent doing menial tasks (manual crafting, traversing the map, delivering ingredients, etc). There's the skeleton of a good game in there somewhere, but many design decisions collectively get in the way of accessing it.

I went in expecting something similar to Katana Zero, but it's so much more than that. Saying Sanabi is a Katana Zero clone would be a huge disservice to this game. To me, both are exceptional gems.

But before I continue to sing my praises to this game, what exactly is Sanabi?

Well, in this action platformer game, you play as a retired veteran with a simple mission, which is to hunt an entity called "Sanabi". To do this, you will use your chain hook prosthetic arm to get around a city called Mago. This weapon can also be used to hook yourself to the enemies, destroying them in the process.

This grappling hook mechanism means that you will spend most of your time in the air, going from one platform to another, from one enemy to another, from one boss to another. And when done right, it feels oh so good, especially because of the tight movement. Makes you feel unstoppable, and it gets the adrenaline pumping!

I said "when done right", because at first, I struggled getting used to the grappling hook gameplay and gamepad controls. Because not only you can hook the enemy, you can boost yourself, slow down time, jump, and so much more. But overtime, I learned to get good and finally experienced that flow state.

Surprisingly, even with this addicting gameplay formula, my favorite part of Sanabi is still the story. Without spoiling anything, you will be confused at first because of the mysteries surrounding Sanabi and Mago are pretty complicated, but once you connect the dots, it will be mind blowing. 

At least mine did, that's for sure. It makes me want to replay the whole game instantly to see all the hints I missed.

Not only mind blowing, Sanabi's story has a lot of heart thanks to its characters. Mind you, Sanabi doesn't have too many characters, since you spend most of your time with a hacker girl named Mari, who's helping you find Sanabi, and her robot companion Mufin.

While Mari might be too talkative to some, I found her character very charming, I really enjoyed her funny personality and antics, and I think the game definitely won't be the same without Mari.

I was too invested in the story of Sanabi, the retired veteran, and Mari. By the end of the game, I was left sobbing my eyes out, heck, I instantly went to write a review, three years after I wrote my previous review.

All of these positive points, combined with the epic soundtracks and the eye catching pixel art, makes the game a complete package worth checking out, even in full price. Scratch that, I insist YOU to try out this game if you love some fast paced action gameplay and heart tugging storytelling.

With that being said, to Wonder Potion a.k.a the developers, I'll be looking forward to your future games! Doesn't matter if it will start as an Early Access product again, I WILL be there!

The game is good, and it's easy to recommend for the price, but it does have an off-putting issue.

The story, the artstyle, the game mechanics, the world-building, and the soundtrack are all top notch. It does however get really tedious at times. It's clearly heavily inspired by Katana Zero, but where Katana Zero effortlessly succeeds in integrating an intriguing plotline with its fast-paced gameplay. This one fails; miserably at times. It felt like the cutscenes and gameplay were constantly interrupting each other, the second you get into the gameplay and are being thrown challenging enemies, you're interrupted by a cutscene twice as long, and when the story gets interesting, you're interrupted with the gameplay. At some point it was hard to enjoy the game cause there was this constant anticipation that the gameplay would come to a grinding halt with a dense cutscene.
I played the speedrun after completing the campaign, and playing it felt leagues better than story mode, the gameplay felt more connected and fluid.
The story is definitely worth experiencing but I don't think it warrants the awful gameplay to cutscene ratio. A lot of it could have been condensed, some of it could have been shown in collectables or records people who are interested could go out of their way to find, having cutscenes between longer sequences of gameplay, etc.

It's good but it would've felt so much better had it put its fast-paced gameplay front and centre, and it seems they could've easily done that.
Has difficulty spikes at times, but worth seeing it to the end.

I have to give this a very reluctant thumbs up.  This is a very good game, but it is certainly not a game that deserves an "Overwhelmingly Positive" tag.  Here's why:

(1) The best part of this game is the story; there is little doubt about that. Though the story is very good, it is absolutely not original, as it is basically an exact copy of a couple very specific movies. Still, the story is worth getting through. I suggest you don't read anything about it and just go through it without any spoilers of any type, even the trailers.

(2) The problem with this "game" is that there is too much emphasis on the story.  You will spend significantly more time watching cut scenes and reading dialogue than actually playing.  That sounds like an exaggeration, but it is 100% true. There is LESS TIME SPENT ON GAMEPLAY THAN ON CUT SCENES. 

(3) The game took some obvious inspiration from Bionic Commando.  Swinging around is fun, but that is basically all you do.  There is little combat here and it is as simplistic as you can possibly get while still calling this a game. 

(4) It way too easy. The challenge of the game is figuring out and becoming adept with the controls.  Once you do that, you fly through the game with ease. 

Some of the reviews compare this to Katana Zero, even saying that it is better than Katana Zero.  I don't think this game is playing in the same league as Katana Zero.  Katana Zero is a far superior game. 

This could have been a legitimate classic if there was more time spent on gameplay and less on cut scenes. This game is a B.  I am not suggesting that you should not play it, as it has its fun parts, but this is really more a movie than a video game.

A fast 'n furious FPS rougelite with co-op. Each character has their own unique in-game upgrade trees, in addition to the overarching meta upgrades you accumulate between runs. There's a lot of different weapons, many of which have their own quirk or special move. I'm a big fan of Daefaning Mortar, a huge energy cannon that can release a close-range burst or an artillery salvo.

Difficulty has its ups and down, with it being possible to stack a lot of damage multipliers and just nuke everything you look at, but conversely it's easy to get killed if you get careless. In co-op you can revive each other, and even in solo play there's the option to add bot teammates. The bots are mostly training wheels, they're practically immortal and will rez you reliably, but they're good for practice or experimenting with wacky builds.

Gotta give the devs credit for handling their new "seasonal" updates tastefully. There's no FOMO involved; You can freely swap around between the different season mechanics, and anything you didn't get in its battlepass equivalent is placed into a general store to unlock with the meta currency already in the game.

Gunfire Reborn has easily become my most-played game. Its charming, cartoony graphics, heavily inspired by Chinese aesthetics, might suggest a lighthearted experience, but the gameplay quickly reveals its challenging roguelite nature. Each run offers a unique experience, heavily influenced by whatever route you choose through your build, so that no two playthroughs are alike. The mechanics are straightforward, yet they allow for intricate and diverse builds that cater to various playstyles. At the time of writing this, I've played over 1100 rounds. It's a great relaxing game, once you get used to it.

The developers’ commitment to consistent updates has enriched the game, introducing fresh challenges and content that keep the experience interesting through every Season. I haven't experienced issues with multiplayer (Sept 2024); it's even better playing with friends. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes simple, relaxing, rougelites with cartoony graphics and a challenging, yet simple to understand, gameplay.

review_text:
Gets old really fast. Content progression is bigger numbers. That's it. Gameplay at zero hour is the same as hour 10. You can set progression speed, so you can get to end-game pretty fast. Base building is mid. If you've played Rust, you've played this. If you've played ARK, you've played this. if you've played Altis Life or GTARP, you've played this. 

If all you want is another flavor of island survival, this is cheap and easy, but this genre is so overdone, its worse than hero shooters and mobas, with none of the complexity or longevity that keeps people playing for years.

review_text: It's a fun game, no doubt. I have logged over 500 hours and completed all but one achievement. That being said, this game has crashed beyond redemption on 4 different occasions. On each occasion I tried saving from old save files, per the instructions given on their website, and it did not resurrect my game. Just recently, the oil rig chests stopped re-spawning, which is the end-game content. The game didn't crash but the chests have not reset in 5 IRL days. Trying to work through older saves does not fix the issue. It is not worth playing this game if you really enjoy it and then cannot play it because you constantly lose all your progress or hit a wall because of glitches and bugs. I use no cheat software or anything else.

review_text:
Firstly Palworld is a fantastic game, it is even better with friends, this is the first reason that I am giving a positive review. 
I love that there is some darkness and there some automation and base building. Its not the most polished game (there are improvements being made all the time though) but it does not have to be, its an absolute blast... Get some friends start a server and put your Pals to work. 
From memory one of the only games I brought at or very close to full price, no regrets. 

The main reason is because nintendo F%^king suck. They have had so long to innovate Pokemon and bring this up to date and in line with other innovative games, Arceus even though this was an innovation for them, for an IP that is so big it was phoned in. 
It sucks to see a beloved franchise like Pokemon stagnate and get wasted like this. Enter Palworld, Pocketpair dared to step up to the line that nintendo drew in the sand and instead of nintendo looking in the mirror for self-reflection and striving for perfection in their games..... They litigate and stifle innovation in companies that are willing to innovate. 

Thank you Pocketpair you truly deserve far more than a positive review for your truly fun game and for standing up for innovation, the community is behind you 100%.

I collected more virginities than I did pokemon.

Getting out the worse part 1st:

- I love sex loving girls, as such, I don't like elements like being brainwashed/hypnotised (aka game is similar to pokemon but only MC get's "lucky" and you get it without me spoiling more), master/toilet... if you played enough H games you know what I mean, but it's not bad in this game since due to "plot" the girls are asking vs other games where the guy force himself. Though I hope this won't be true later on....

- I am not a fan of fetishes involving body fluids, and while "it"'s white for the most part, when "finishing" "it"'s yellow with tons of "it" that is just truly disgusting since it reminds me of rotten... you know what, let me not finish. Because again... this is just the "bad part" section"

- For the adult restoration patch, you need to create and account and buy (free, no card details and so on) from the publisher's website. And I hope I make it clear it's only for +18. And just for your own info, if you got the DLC (Steam) for this game, on the publishers website, you don't need both patches, just the one with the DLC (again, free), since that one covers both the standard as well as the DLC (around 2 GB)
-Bad endings... you know what, let me not even open this topic...

Neutral
-/+ you are stuck with partner since it's very important for the story, aka you can't replace.
-/+ just like in pokemon you need/there is a lot to explore and battle other trainers
-/+ H Scenes are set, so this does lack the freedom to chose "preferences"
-/+ Art of the monsters, as well as MC. I can't how many, but most of the monster, I saw in other rpg maker games, aka I assume they are free to use art...

Now the good part:
+ While not everything, this game is a better version of the early Pokemon games. And it's very good on top.
+ Nothing to complicated, aka if you want easily win every battle just select easy
+ The +18 art is one of the best I saw for RPG Maker type of game. Only visual novels and Hentai videos had better then this game, but few RPG maker type (maybe some Wolf RPG ones but I'm going off course), and it's also Uncensored (no mosaic) including X ray for some. The angle is also amazing since you can see very well what you want. Also, while it's not video animation, aka still looped images but give the sensation of being animated, it it's once again, one of the best GIF CG I saw in any RPG Maker game.
+ It's fun to play, explore, chat with NPC for extra info (sometimes), and find new events.
+ Steam has a "if less then 2 hours played in less then 2 weeks since patches, you can refund for full price", and I am sure that said 2 hours is more then enough for you to tell if you like this game (even if not everything).

This game is amazing. story is phenomenal, very well written has quiet a few twists i did not expect. I would highly recommend the base game to anyone that likes pokemon clones. The H stuff on the other hand is pretty vanilla till the end of the game. The post game on the other hand has anything you could ask for.

for clarity this review was done with the DLC and 18+ patch enabled so things might be different in some ways if you don't have these installed.

If you are a fan of creature collecting games, this one is worth giving a try. It's got a a simple to understand combat system and a surprisingly good story for an adult themed game that you wouldn't expect. The character designs are really well done, I like how every character has their own visual design to stand out and give them personality. The H-scenes are a bit choppy at times, probably the biggest weakness of the game if you install the patches but there are still some entertaining scenes as well. They do feel a bit heavy at times when you are just trying to push through the game though. 

 combat consists of Yarimon that fall into 1 of 7 types. water, fire, wind, earth, dark, light and normal. with normal doing neutral damage against all types. water>fire>wind>earth>water and finally dark and light both being strong against the other. It's a very simple system with every Yarimon weakness told to you at the start of a battle so there is no guess work.

When it comes to moves, there is no PP like you would find in pokemon but it does have a cooldown system. Of your 4 moves weaker attacks will be able to be used back to back and as you learn more powerful moves, you will find that they have longer cooldowns which adds a surprising amount of depth you wouldn't really expect. As for difficulty, I did a run that didn't use the cheat tackle move which will 1 shot any Yarimon but is limited to 1 time a battle.this added a level of difficulty that wasn't too hard to overcome with a bit of experience but did create a few challenges in the early game. 

Going more into the difficulty, one thing I really enjoyed was that you weren't allowed to over level your Yarimon from the start of the game. Your Yarimon are capped at your trainer level which only increases when you defeat another trainer so there is very little reason to grind on wild Yarimon. This also makes trainer battles important and finding trainers that you can defeat becomes a challenge you need to overcome in the early game. When it comes to trainers, you will never be forced into a battle with one. You can always decline a battle and before the battle starts, you get to see how many and at what level the opponents Yarimon are so you will not be caught off guard when entering a fight. 

No creature collecting game is complete without a good share of monsters to collect and Yarimono offers 151 (plus your starter) Yarimon to collect. Almost all Yarimon can evolve  besides approximately 5, 3 of which are your legendary trio stand ins. At the start of battles you can attempt to catch a Yarimon and after using an item on it, then after defeating it in battle it will join you without fail. No random luck required. Same thing goes with running away, running is always 100% successful making finding the Yarimon you are looking for a breeze. Throw in a handy little info section in the bottom right of every screen and whenever you enter grass you will know exactly what Yarimon appear there so you can easily find what ones you haven't befriended yet. Very helpful.

Finally the story might be the biggest surprise with me. I didn't think a game that combines adult content and creature capturing was going to have a splatted together story but I was dead wrong. As you make your way through the ranks to try and become the Yarimon Champion and with the Yarimon Tournament, there begins to be signs of a pretty dark and sinister events going on. Without going too much into details, the story gave me vibes of gens 6 and 8 of pokemon. The story even finds a way to tie in your own characters childhood and early game weakness as well as explain why the adult content stuff is happening. All in all, there is a lot more to the story than I would have given it credit for going in. I was surprised how much the story hooked me.


overall i think the game is a solid 8 out of 10. It isn't extremely long, I was able to do a single play through getting all the achievements and unlocking everything there was to see over 3 days in slightly under 20 hours. I finished the game at level 144 which may seem like a lot but it really isn't as DLC trainers can get up to 159 (might be higher). If you like creature collection give this game a shot.

This review was written after completing everything in the game other than DLC fights and collecting all 151 Yarimons. So I'd say 10-15 hours is the amount of game play time you'll get from this game. I also play with the patch that can be downloaded from the publisher's website and this review will be based on that.

Overall, Yarimono is a solid game that's worth the price I paid for. HOWEVER, before you buy the game, I'd recommend looking Nyuu's work online first. While I enjoyed the art style a lot, I know that some people dislike it and it might ended up not being your cup of tea.

In terms of game play, it is similar to other catch-em-all games out there. So I'm not gonna touch on that too much and other reviews can probably give deeper insights than mine.

I will, however, talk about the eroge aspect of the game in a bit more detail. There are 76 partners that have a scene with you, with multiple having more than one scenes. In total, I'd estimate the amount of unique scenes close to 130-150 scenes. Each scene are drawn well, and all have some animation to go along with it, which I think is a nice touch.

In terms of theme, it stays true to Nyuu's style of brainwash, ugly bastard, with a side of urination. This is why I strongly recommend looking their work first before getting the game, since these themes might not be everyone's cup of tea. With that said, those who don't mind these themes will definitely enjoy what the game has to offer.

As for the story, I'd put it around 6-7/10. There are emotional moments for sure and it's better than 90% of the eroges out there. However, it still is pretty simple and straightforward. There will be moments that felt weird or forced to make the plot moves. There are also some weird translations and typo if you're playing on the English version. Most dialogues will still make sense, but it just wouldn't flow too well. 

With that said, this game is an easy recommendation for me. I definitely enjoyed it.

Unexpectedly good story, like, very good story.

Very solid H-game, I really enjoyed the art style though I wasn't necessarily the biggest fan of the "ugly protagonist" trope. Still, the scenes are well drawn and well animated. 10/10 on art style

 The game itself is also very great, there absolutely is difficulty in the game if you choose to avoid using the "cheat tackle" move and it stands on its own as a solid monster-taming game. 8/10 on gameplay

The story... was far better than I was expecting it to be. Had some pretty great twists that I did not see coming, and it did a good job of bringing it all together towards the end, I had moments where I was starting to piece things together before things were actually revealed. 9/10 on story

Overall I would say this game is a strong 9/10 and absolutely worth the full price, as I've definitely gotten my moneys worth and more out of it. I would love to play additional DLC or a sequel to this.

review_text:
Been playing this game for years now, so here are my 2 cents on the game for new players.

This game is hard, like vary hard, if you are new you will die a lot to older players.  So here are a few things you can do to get better at the game.

1. Don't cheat.  You will not get better if you do cheat and you will make the game worse by doing so.
2. Listen to your surroundings.  This can make you win or loss a game just because you could not hear where the other players shots are coming from so you put your back towards the player shooting at you instead of facing them.
3. Do not land at popular sites, this is an easy and fast way to go back to the lobby, instead look for locations at least 1km from where the plane is flying and go there.
4. Play with friends and use VOIP.  You can use the in game VOIP, but what I use is Discord.
5. Don't go more then 100 m from your team mates.  This way when one of you is in trouble, 3 of your team mates are at positions to aid you.  Also don't be to close to each other, as this makes you easier to spot and makes it harder for you and your team mates to return fire when you are in a fire fight.
6. When you see someone, ping them so your team mates know where they are and can aid it taking them down.
7. Take a automatic weapon and a long range weapon (DMR or SR).  My suggestion for a new player is a SMG and a DMR.  For SMG use one of the 3, UMP, VECTOR, MP5K.  As for DMR's, use SLR or DRAGUNOV.
8. Carry at least 4 First Aid kits, 10 bandages, and 4 boosts.
9. Carry 2-3 Smoke grenades.
10. Just have fun.

review_text: The player who uses the perspective cheating function cheats by reporting the location to his teammates. When the player is killed, he can only report the cheating teammate but not the cheater. He can only enter the spectator mode after the whole team dies. However, the cheating team often leaves one member of our team unkilled, making it impossible for the player to spectate the cheating team and accurately find the perspective cheater.

EA FC 25 has become much more than just a football simulation game—it’s an obsession for many, almost to the point of addiction. The game’s allure lies not only in its realistic gameplay but in the psychological hooks embedded within its most popular mode, Ultimate Team. Here, players build their dream squads by purchasing and opening virtual packs, hoping to land high-rated players. The randomness of the pack openings, combined with the constant updates of new content and challenges, can feel like a never-ending cycle, which easily mirrors the addictive behaviors seen in gambling. Spending real money on virtual packs in EA FC 25 often feels like buying lottery tickets, with the dopamine rush from landing a rare player driving players to keep spending, hoping for better results next time. This practice has been widely criticized for promoting gambling habits, particularly among younger players, who might not fully grasp the financial consequences.

Personally, EA FC 25 triggers a unique frustration. Despite investing hours into perfecting skills, tweaking formations, and optimizing my Ultimate Team, the game often feels unfair. Matches can be decided by tiny, sometimes random moments—an AI glitch, a poor refereeing decision, or a lucky bounce—leaving me feeling powerless. What makes it worse is when the players you worked so hard (or spent so much) to acquire seem to underperform, leading to pure rage. The gameplay mechanics sometimes feel deliberately designed to push you into spending more, as if the better players you need to succeed are always just out of reach, unless you're willing to pay. This cycle of frustration, combined with the temptation of opening "just one more pack," turns what should be a fun experience into something more stressful and, at times, toxic. The game manages to tap into that part of your brain that makes you feel like you’re on the verge of a breakthrough, but in reality, it’s pulling you deeper into the grind, causing more frustration and emotional investment than it should.

I'll mostly just be reinforcing what many of the other reviews are saying. This is not Frostpunk 1, but bigger and better. This is a new game, with the same setting, similar themes are atmosphere, etc., but this is a new game. I like this new game, others may not. I don't recommend simply buying this because you liked Frostpunk 1. Look at this like it's a fresh game and ask yourself if it looks like the kind of game for you.

And I don't think any of this is a problem. It's not like it's totally disconnected from Frostpunk 1. They wanted to take a crack at it from a totally different angle. Power to them. I wish more games companies did things like this. Take risks, try new ideas, see what happens. Easier said than done, of course.
Amazing sequel

A proper sequel. Takes everything from the first to a more grand scale. Abstracts away 'wood vs iron', for instance, in favor of factions and a council where laws are proposed and deals are made. Loving the gold accents in the menu and visuals. Soundtrack is gas. Yet these are only icing on the already delicious post-apocalyptic society-builder cake.

The game takes great strides to make things feel personal, as in how individuals in your society respond to events and feel. This, despite many reviewers claiming that they feel disconnected from individual workers, for example. My opinion is that what these reviewers want is another Frostpunk expansion, and that's fine. Just don't miss out on this incredibly well done sequel.

Masterpiece. Game of the year for me.

I didn't play the first one, but heard much about it. So I'm not comparing it to anything, but to me this game is a masterclass in immersion and natural as well as guided storytelling. The mechanics are great and feel different from other games. It's original. The game doesn't hold your hand, the prologue serves as a tutorial, but doesn't feel like a tutorial: You're immediately fighting for survival, but the game never feels unfair. Here and there I wished the consequences of my actions were clearer, but you can always reload, and I suggest making multiple saves. I never got soft locked, but I'm sure you can.

You explore the world as you explore mechanics and the story unfolds. The story feels very authentically interlinked with what you do. When factions were mad at me, they had good reason to, and they all have reasonable stances, that just happen to conflict very often. Moral choices are nuanced.

You will be managing and balancing dozens of things at the same time, have to make sacrifices, sometimes heavy ones, but you always have clear and realistic short and long-term goals. Some self-imposed, some from the game's plot, and some just to keep your people alive and if possible, happy. For a city management game it's extremely exciting. Oftentimes I barely scraped by.

Other developers can learn from this. How to trust your audience: show them the basic with more show than tell, then throw them into the cold water and let them figure it out.

Special shout out to the the graphics and sound design. It's actually a very pretty game and I wish I could zoom in more (the zoom-in on generators doesn't do it for me).

Now that I finished the campaign I can't wait to play the sandbox mode, which seems pretty fleshed out with 7 starting locations and completely different factions from story mode.

Usually when you hear about a sequel its a toss up between "here we go again" or a "Wow! They really improved it." What the devs did with Frostpunk 2 is revamp the game to be almost a new game. 

You feel the constant pressure of your choices. Everything is on the brink of collapse as you try to balance the politics, failing machinery, and ever encroaching cold with resources that are few and far and between. This truly feels like a "survival, post-apocalyptic setting". You desperately need more food, you finally find some frozen food stores under the ice. So you go to build an extraction district to try and pull the resources out. Some of the workforce mining the coal out of the ice died from starvation or the frost. Now you do not have enough workers. So you pull from another area. Some of the children start to go feral as the city starts to descend into anarchy. The coal mine is not producing coal as it dries up, so your generator holding the cold barely at bay is running out of fuel now.  You make a deal with a colony for some of their oil to keep the heat on for a little longer. In doing so, one of the rising factions in the city begins to oppose you because they do not like the deal you made. 

Its a constant struggle of back and forth that makes you feel you are really on the precipice of extinction and about to go over. 
Game play is outstanding. Graphics and audio are great. Some audio sound bite loops (such as when you click on one of the factions) can get old fast. Minor nitpicking aside, this game is absolutely fantastic. No you do not need to buy the first game at all. This is well worth the 45 bucks to a somewhat small studio for game play that is infinitely better than any of the sludge the "AAA" studios will ever produce.

tldr; Good base of a game, wait for some patches to come out and fix the QoL issues. If there was a neutral rating I would give it. There is a good core of the game here, keeping much of the spirit of the first game.There is a good core of the game here, keeping much of the spirit of the first game.

Pros 
1 - Game looks great. Good atmosphere and art on the menus. Colors and well done to lean into the overall dystopia steam punk vibe. 

2 - More of a natural society progression. You don't just get to choose what society you'll be with a simple choice. Your laws, the factions you favor and your choices in events grow your society. This leads to tech and law unlocks. Makes for a fun RP experience and something refreshing to see in a city builder.

3 - Most of the core mechanics of the first game are intact, so resources and heat management especially are still very much the priority.  

4 - Game still has a great soundtrack and atmosphere all around.

Neutral 

1 -  It's on a larger scale than the first game so you don't build individual buildings, you just build districts. Your ascetic control of your colony is basically non-existent. For me this is irksome, but this really comes down to a personal preference. I miss being able to craft my colony to look a certain way. But this is purely an ascetic issue and I can't knock the game for it. 

Cons 

1 - This game should have an early access tag. It has several small bugs that can really just kill your run. You'll spend some amount of time online trying to figure out what happened until you realize it's a bug.
                - Example - First scenario in new london, you establish a colony for oil. My progress just stopped even with ample frost teams. I paused all other outpots to get more frost teams, that did not restart progress. When I sent people to establish the colony, it reduce the number of works in all my buildings in new london. This caused me to have less frost teams. Even after increasing worker count, my colony would not progress in building. Had to reload. Seems like a minor bug, but annoying because if you don't catch it right away it can kill your run.


2 - QoL is poor. Resource management is an integral part of this game. Everything is a slider when it comes to resources, being workers or raw materials. Some you can get precise numbers on because the slider also has small button allowing 1 quantity changes. Others do not have this option, because reasons. So you sometimes have exact control over how many workers are somewhere, or how many resources you send/receive. Other times you just get to throw a handful of workers at a new colony and hope it's close enough to the number you want. Also you can't scroll with arrow key, or middle mouse with the sliders either. Just click and hold. You also can't cancel buildings in progress, and if you lay a building down wrong have to just deal with it later. You also while planning to build, can only cancel in sequential order. Can't click on a tile to cancel just one and build somewhere else. Minor issue but again, just more lifting for the user for seemingly no reason. 

3 - UI is bad, like all form over function bad. You can hotkey to most important things, which is fine. You can also hover over your resources and most of the numbers up top to see a better breakdown. But the idea to have the 5 categories hang below your top UI not really be intractable at all is baffling to me. The worse they get, the longer the tail they get, which can end up cluttering the top of your screen. You also get zero information about them. Some are derived stats, some are all ready covered in your resource needs. They feel redundant and don't serve much purpose beyond the look. You also cannot short cut most actions in a district. It has an empty building slot? Well can't click on the building slot to do anything. Have to exit looking at the district, go to your buildings build menu which is different from your district build menu, find the right sub category for the building you want, then select it. Seems like a minor gripe but like...you can't build any of the buildings outside of their specific district type besides heat ones. Why do they need their own menu, why can they not be done from the district menu? They're upgrades, not independent items. Game becomes more dependent on pause with small things like this. 

4 - Game is gonna chug after you set up some colonies and managing more than one city. Needs some performance optimization.
Lots of Snow! Two Frostbitten Thumbs Up!

Good as the first game

The game looks very nice in terms of graphics, but they tried to innovate on too many new mechanics, way too diversified from the first Frostpunk, and for me they clearly failed. It's very unpolished; they just tried to implement on top of the old version, but it feels and plays way worse. They tried to overcomplicate it with fancy menus and choices with 100 drop-down menus; it just feels like they put all these things in there just to have more options without thinking about the fun in the game, like the first one. It just feels like a mess; there is no clear way to describe it, but coming from over 142.8 hours in the first game, this feels like a different Frostpunk game... Sad, but maybe I expected too much to be like the first game and just be better (upgraded).

Frostpunk 2's user interface feels overly complicated and cluttered compared to the streamlined design of the first game. The shift away from the neatness of the original makes it difficult to understand what’s happening at times, with too much filler content. Some research options appear across multiple tabs, causing confusion, and there’s a noticeable lack of quality-of-life features like the ability to cancel construction. Additionally, heat continues to be consumed even when a district is turned off, which feels counterintuitive. The six-slot district system seems like a questionable design choice, though it’s not my main issue. While I love the direction the game has taken, the execution feels lacking, with clutter and disorganisation detracting from the experience.

Frostpunk 2 does justice to the original while bringing some interesting new game play. Overall it emphasizes a macro approach, with the overall scale of "The City" and its inhabitants dialed all the way up. The population count is higher, there are more resource/types, you can create and maintain more than one city/settlement during a run, and the faction system is dynamic. I do miss the small scale of Frostpunk 1 at times. Starting off with a handful of settlers and watching them trudge throw snow and ice, some freezing to death, in a desperate effort to collect enough coal and other resources to survive. Frostpunk 2s larger scale results in not experiencing or witnessing your citizens in the same way, but overall there can be no doubt Frostpunk 2 will be a successful sequel.

We will win against the frost.

While I very much enjoy the game, I still have very mixed feelings about it. The change in scale from the original, as others have pointed out, makes things a bit less impactful. I find myself going, "well, that's the cost of doing business" way too much.
However, my biggest issue is that, despite the delayed release, the game really could've benefited from another few months in the oven to polish off some of the more obvious bugs. For example, I've encountered a few weird UI glitches. That's to say nothing of the day-1 patch "temporary fix" for what is a pretty jarring audio crackling issue in big cities. It's not a good look to release it like this.

Please, developers, and I mean all game developers, not just 11-Bit Studios: Polish off your games. People will forgive less obvious bugs, but when you release a game with glaring issues that *had* to have been apparent prior to release, it's really bad form. Day-1 patches for these kinds of issues don't really mitigate the optics, in my book. Day-1 patches say to me, "we know the game isn't finished, but we're releasing it anyway."

In conclusion, this is a tentative "not recommended" from me, purely on the grounds of it being released without solving the aforementioned obvious bugs. I'm confident these issues will be fixed soon, but the game being released in this state leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

I was disappointed starting at 'build district' and it hasn't gotten better. It's Frostpunk minus the charm, grit, and detail that made the first game so excellent. If I was new to the franchise and you told me this was the first game and the original was Frostpunk 2, I'd believe it.
if your buying this because you enjoyed FP1, understand your not buying the same game. I'm having a difficult time getting into FP2, its very different, too different imo.

Overall, I did enjoy this game. It does feel like a natural progression from Frostpunk 1, in terms of scale. In both games, resource management is important and have far-reaching consequences if you do not manage it well. I do agree with some reviews that in Frostpunk 2, you don't feel as attached to the individuals when compared to Frostpunk 1. People, at least to a degree, are just numbers. But I did enjoy the statements from individual characters in the game in general. However, when I finished the main story, I wouldn't help but wonder if I did my best, or whether I did the right thing. All I could say was an attempt was made. I would argue there was an emotional attachment involved in Frostpunk 2, but not to the individual. Rather, I felt more attached to the city itself. Achieving that isn't easy and I do applaud 11-Bit Studios for taking a risk here. The game did do a good job at making things feel desperate near the end but I do admit, the music wasn't as noticeable for some reason.

Overall I did like the game, but I am not sure I liked this game as much as Frostpunk 1. I really do enjoy the lore however.

This is obviously the worst PES game I've ever played. But it shows that Konami wants to get away from the recycle-old-game-and-stick-a-new-name-on scheme. Some ideas and approaches are very good (more movements without the ball, cross-play, transitionless corners and throw-ins, etc...), but the implementation is very miserable. To be honest, even old functions that have always worked flawlessly are miserable now. In the end, this just shows how hard it actually is to bring a completely new game to market instead of remarketing the same game for full price. I like the approach of putting more effort into the football games, bringing new features and taking risks. It's a shame that PES flopped this year, but since it's free, you shouldn't bitch so much. Kudos to Konami for daring to make this right step. I'll wait for EFootball until it's ready.

Edit.

The updated version of EFootball is not comparable to the beta version which was very criticized. The game runs very smoothly and I hardly had any bugs, the graphics and animations look very realistic especially on high graphics settings. The game dynamics are rarely disturbed by fading to freekicks or throw-ins, the game continues to run while the players are getting the ball ready, which is very good. When there are cut scenes they are well used and hardly interfere. It feels more like watching a game on TV.
The game dynamics have also improved a lot, offensive players move smartly and the defense also makes few mistakes. In order to get a goal situation you have to either trick the opponent to open up passing situations or outplay the opponent with well-directed passes. At the moment, besides the friendly matches and online games, there is only the Dream Team mode, where you create and manage a team online and play against the AI or online games. It is good that you can buy the standard players directly and do not have to pull from "packs". These then start at level 0 and you have to level them up to their normal value and then you can go a bit beyond that. Very good I found here the possibility that you can choose the value upgrades yourself and thus can form your perfect player. You can e.g. skill MBappe to be more focused on speed and dribbling to let him play more on the wing or increase the values for finishing and attacking to set him up as a center forward. The choice is up to you. Since Efootball is free, there is a fear that the game will become pay-to-win. So far, however, I have been able to do well with my non-pay-to-win team and have not had the feeling that I had a big disadvantage compared to the other players. The good thing is that Featured players and the "normal form" of the same players usually have the same values when they are at the highest level. Featured players just start at a higher value and don't need to level up as long. Also, Featured players often have an alternate focus on skills. Only some legend players that are hard to get are a lot better than the "normal" counterparts. I would have been happy if legendaries had been just as good and you only acquired them, for example, if you were a big fan, so as not to break the balance of the game. But so far opponents had only 2-3 legends in the team and the difference was not so big that you have no chance against them.

As a fan of Crusader Kings II, I was excited to try Crusader Kings III, and it did not disappoint. The mechanics have been refined and expanded, making the game even more immersive. My first campaign was a wild ride, and I loved it.

I started as Duchess Matilda of Tuscany, and things quickly went out of control. After committing the "crime" of fornication, I had to deal with the consequences not once, but twice: first, when the child was born, and then when someone blackmailed me to reveal the father’s identity. I refused. My liege, Kaiser Heinrich IV of the Holy Roman Empire, decided to arrest me twice, ruining my reputation and legitimacy. To make matters worse, he revoked some of my titles, reducing me from a Duchess to a Countess.

I plotted an assassination scheme against the Kaiser, and to my surprise, it worked. With a new liege, I set my sights on recovering my lost titles. I declared war on my Duke and, after a tense battle, managed to reclaim two of them. While I didn't get back all of my original titles (I went from 6 down to 4), it was still a lot of fun.

By the end of Matilda's life, she held 10 titles. It was an unexpected journey, but that’s what makes the game so enjoyable, you never quite know where things will end up.

Worst sequel ive ever seen, literally took all the joy and fun out of ck2 and stripped all the dlc from ck2 just so that they could re-release it one at a time over the course of the next 25 years with random "Culture packs" sprinkled throughout for $25 a pop. Easily a scam.

The reasons I'm recommending this probably differ from that of a lot of other players. (My total playing hours are over 100 by the way but started on a different clock).

The reasons are in two categories, (a) the unexpected playability factor and (b) the medieval simulator factor.

A - Playability - Paradox have finally found the sweet spot between complexity and accessibility. I did not come to CK3 with much hope of enjoying it, much less being any good at it. I say that because I've struggled and indeed given up on other Paradox games, finding them intimidating, the learning curve too steep, decision paralysis etc. Somehow with CK3 Paradox has finally nailed the combination of deploying myriad extremely deep and complex mechanics, but making them (just) accessible enough to get into. It's like you can put your toe in the shallow end and gradually wade in until the game consumes you. I've also learned enough from my first playthrough of CK3 that I feel like now I can take another look at those other Paradox games I'd given up on (looking at you, EU4....) because I now feel like I understand much more of the fundamentals and meta-mechanics of a Paradox grand strategy game that I simply couldn't wrap my head around until CK3.

That is NOT to say CK3 is "easy" or "simple". Far from it...it's a deep and rewarding game that also manages to capture the 'just one more turn' addictiveness of the Civilization series despite it being real-time (with pause at will), not turn based. That is a massive hat-tip and compliment from me.

How does Paradox manage to bring the 'just one more turn' impulse to a real-time grand strategy game? Read on for the next category:

B - A medieval simulator: This game memorably recreates the sheer chaos and unpredictability of medieval history by simulating how the smallest event can set of a chain of instability that brings carefully laid plans to ruin...and then stunning reversals to reclaim glory from ashes.

The game gives life to the old saying 'for want of a nail, the Kingdom was lost...' because seemingly insignificant relationships, events, minor misdeeds can suddenly cascade into realm-wide catastrophe....but it's neither random nor "unfair"...one can experience how everyday events had real-world consequences on a massive scale during this incredible period of history.

CK3 has done what no other Paradox game could...got me playing, enjoying it, and keeping on for 'just one more turn'...!

Having loved Crusader Kings II, I went into CK3 with high hopes. After spending a good amount of time with the game, I can say that while I like Crusader Kings III, I’ll never feel as excited about it as I was with its predecessor. The leap from CK2 to CK3 feels minor in terms of gameplay evolution — outside of the graphical improvements, the core mechanics haven’t been significantly expanded upon.

Unfortunately, the major issue that plagued CK2, namely repetitiveness, hasn't been adequately addressed. There are moments of brilliance, and it's still a fun game for those who enjoy grand strategy, but it lacks the depth and novelty to keep me as engaged as CK2 did over the years.

If you’re new to the series, CK3 is a solid place to start. But for veterans of CK2, the experience may feel more familiar than fresh.

If you’ve ever wondered what it would be like to survive in a world overrun by zombies, Project Zomboid is the game for you. With a heavy focus on realism and player choice, this survival sandbox offers a deeply immersive experience that few other games can match. Whether you’re managing your character’s health, building your dream base, or evading hordes of undead, Project Zomboid keeps you on your toes at every moment. Having spent over 730 hours in the game, I can confidently say that it delivers one of the best survival experiences available today.

1. Realism Done Right
Despite the fictional backdrop of a zombie apocalypse, Project Zomboid nails realism in almost every aspect of gameplay. The most valuable tip for any new player is simply: "What would you do in this situation?" The game's health system is intricate, with injuries, illnesses, and mental states all playing a role. Clothes protect you from zombie bites, degrade over time, and help regulate body temperature, which is vital. Mechanics like repairing vehicles, dealing with character traits and professions, and managing inventory weight make everything feel real. I especially love how character emotions and moods affect gameplay – it’s small touches like these that elevate Project Zomboid to another level of immersion.

2. An Open World That Never Ends
The current game world is massive, and despite having played over 730 hours, I still didn't explore all the areas. I admire the sheer size of the map, and with upcoming updates promising to expand it further and even include randomly generated maps in the distant future. Project Zomboid also offers infinite gameplay and replayability. It’s one of those survival games you can play over and over without ever getting tired.

3. Sandbox Customization Options
One of my favorite aspects is the ability to tailor the world to your liking. From the number and behavior of zombies to loot distribution, characters (players), and more, Project Zomboid lets you tweak almost anything. It gives you the power to create a world that fits your personal playstyle or challenge yourself with tougher scenarios.

4. Character Creation and Professions
This is hands-down one of my favorite features in the game. Choosing different professions and character traits, both positive and negative, significantly changes how the game plays. I also appreciate the subtle bonuses and drawbacks that aren’t immediately obvious – it adds an extra layer of depth. The balance in this system is present, too, so don’t expect to create an overpowered character unless you tweak the sandbox settings to do so!

5. Community Mods
While Project Zomboid doesn’t need mods to be great, the fact that they’re available is a huge bonus. The modding community has added incredible content, from enhanced realism to new vehicles, traits, weapons, and crafting options. There’s too much to describe in one review! That said, I recommend playing without mods at first to truly grasp the game’s mechanics, but later on, mods can make the experience even better.

6. Skill Levels and Physical Attributes
Project Zomboid features an extensive skill system that allows players to improve their characters through practice and experience. Skills are divided into categories like combat, crafting, survival, and agility, each having a noticeable impact on gameplay. Combat skills such as aiming and reloading become crucial for firearm users, while melee skills like blunt and blade proficiency determine how effective you are with weapons like baseball bats or axes. Crafting skills, including carpentry, metalworking, and tailoring, let you fortify your base, repair clothes, or even create tools from scratch.
Survival skills like foraging and fishing allow you to live off the land when resources run dry, and farming lets you grow your own food, providing a sustainable source of nutrition. Agility skills, such as sneaking and lightfooted, are essential for staying hidden from zombies, while sprinting helps you escape when the situation gets dire.
Physical attributes like strength and fitness are equally important, as they directly affect how much weight you can carry, how fast you tire, and how effective you are in combat. Improving your strength means you can carry heavier loads and hit harder with melee attacks, while better fitness ensures you can run longer distances and recover faster from exhaustion. Each skill progresses the more you use it, making every action in the game feel meaningful and rewarding.

7. Intriguing (But Optional) Lore
While the storyline isn’t central to the player’s experience yet, it does exist, and it’s fascinating. I only started diving into the game’s lore after playing for about 500 hours, and once I did, I was hooked. I went so far as to read up on the game’s backstory online (beware of spoilers!) Exploring the lore adds a new dimension to the game. I highly recommend getting to know the lore yourself!

8. A Sandbox Experience
Want to build? Build. Want to destroy? Go ahead. In Project Zomboid, your creativity (and characters human possibilities) are your only limits. The only challenge is gathering materials, which makes sense given the post-apocalyptic setting. But with enough time and motivation, you can accomplish incredible things. This open-ended approach is perfect for players who enjoy creating and building their own worlds.

9. Active Developer Support
The game is still in early access, and while it may not be updated on a daily basis, the developers deliver large, meaningful updates. They listen to player feedback, fix bugs, and continue to improve the game without ignoring the community, which is something I greatly respect.

10. Hidden Depths
Just when you think you’ve learned everything there is to know about Project Zomboid, it surprises you. The game is full of hidden mechanics and features that add to the depth of the experience. I’ve had several moments where I thought I had mastered the game, only to discover a new layer of complexity. It’s a game that keeps on giving.

11. Fair Price
Finally, let’s talk about the price. For what Project Zomboid offers, the price is perfect. But if you’re looking to save a bit of money, it’s always worth waiting for a sale. Either way, you’re getting your money’s worth for this gem of a game.

Project Zomboid is a truly exceptional survival game that combines deep realism with sandbox freedom. Whether you're fighting off zombies, building your own fortress, or scavenging for supplies, every moment feels impactful. With continuous updates, an active modding community, and endless replayability, it’s a game that will keep you coming back for more. I can’t recommend it highly enough to fans of survival games or anyone looking for a challenging, immersive experience.

Definitely really tried to like this game. The art and music is amazing, but the game is EXTREMELY grindy. 

The game definitely feels like it doesn't respect your time with a fairly large map that takes awhile to move around in. Making things such as a minecart network feels like a hassle, since mine carts  / boats aren't equipped to your character, but placed on the rail network, so if you die, you'll have to walk all the way back to get your vehicle.  Fast travel points are few and far between, and the only way (As far as I know) to create an additional fast travel point is extremely resource intensive and has a TEN minute cooldown.

You'll also need a large amount of materials for a lot of stuff in the game, which the game seems to flirt with automating the process a bit by having automated drills to get these resources for you.  The way you can automate things is extremely basic however, and will require you to just randomly explore until you find an appropriate node you can place your drills at. 

The gearing for combat in this game also feels pretty basic, and doesn't have as much synergies as I'd like. For example, I equipped an armour set that increases crit chance upon poisoning an enemy. However I found that this trait doesn't proc when using a range weapon that poisons enemies, when using a character skill that inflicts poison whenever you deal damage, or when using a pet that poisons enemies. It seems to only proc when using a poison melee weapon - which wasn't mentioned in the description of the armour set. 

The breaking point for me in this game was [spoiler] A large underwater sea section, which you basically need a boat for traveling around at. There's a water boss in this section without a fast travel point near it. Dying to it not only means having to make the long trek back, but you'll either need to remake your really expensive boat or make a long land bridge back to your stuff[/spoiler]

Ultimately, I was looking for something to scratch my survival crafting itch, but there's not enough here to justify the massive grind.

I have never been into 2d games, I have never been into civ building, I have never been into indie games. 

And I love this! Time flies when you are playing this.

I did a full play through with a friend in a single seed to 100% the game in a little over 120 hours.  The progression of this game is fantastic and the crafting system is easy to use/follow.  Go-karts, Boating, PvE, PVP, boss battles... I was never bored playing this game as there is always something to do.  The customization you are allowed to make in game is endless (painting, flooring, walls, farming, automation, mob spawning, etc.).  Essentially you need to defeat certain bosses to gather parts to power the core, which will unlock more of the available map.  There are also optional bosses, ALL of which have fun mechanics and I recommend trying all boss fights.  The appearance of the game to me was appealing, giving almost a retro feel to the game.  This game felt like it took great aspects from other games I've played and put it into one. 
 Very fun game, definitely recommend it.  

Things I've learned/tips:
1.)  Using the Map - to place the Icons, select the desired icon and click the middle mouse button on the map to add; click on same spot to remove.  Mark boss fighting/summoning locations to find easier later on.
2.)  If you want to customize flooring that doesn't allow it to be painted; put a "glass floor" on top of it, then paint it.  May find a color you like w/ that pattern.
3.)  Create Scanners to find bosses, sooo much more convenient than blindly running around the map.
4.)  Save the figurines you collect.  There's a way to "power" them to have them spawn that type of mob; they do not drop loot, though still grant exp for your skill ups.
5.)  You have 3 different gear sets, recommend binding those sets to hotkeys.  Some fights may be much easier if/when you switch armor sets/tactics during the fight.

Hope the above helps, enjoy!
Better than WB platform fighter

The game has been super fun. Started with hard mode and it provided enough of a challenge to keep the game interesting. The game provides enough variety of activities to keep you exploring without tiring out from any one activity. When you get tired of fishing, for example, you move on to something else for a while. 

I'm not a min/max kind of player, so I do my own builds with whatever I find via natural play through and was able to find some of the legendary weapons in good time. Ranged weapons are very good in this game, especially physical ranged like the daggers. Overall, Armor sets favor physical melee and ranged builds. There are some for casters or summoners as well, but they aren't very strong end game and fall off fast. Mainly because there are only two books to summon creatures. At some point  the mana cost gets to be too high and the bats are too dumb for combat situations to really focus on summons and I found myself using daggers or other weapons like the fireball staff to compensate. I really really tried making a summoner build work on its own, but I couldn't get through some of the content even though I was geared fairly well. Switched to physical range and beat everything no problem. At the time of me writing this, I have only the remaining two titans left, which I'm about to tackle next. 

Good game and definitely worth playing. Can't wait to see what else they'll add. Hoping that summoners get some more love

40 hrs so far and for the most part, Ive really had a good time. I do feel like the game suffers from an identity crisis. Does it want to be an open world survival like Minecraft, something casual like Stardew Valley, or more of a Boss a Rush type of game?

The postive thing ia that you get a little bit of all 3, but the negative is that you have to deal with game mechanics that intentionally slow you down.

Example, Trying to farm Wool, but you can only do it every 10 real time minutes. Bosses that have a cooldown before they respawn. Or farming for the 3 upgrade materials, Emearld,Ruby, and Sapphire which take forever without a Mob spawner. 

If you can look past the obnoxious grind for materials, I think youll enjoy your stay here. Alot of these materials arent necessary until later in the game depending on how fast you push into the next zone.


Boss are cool. Lots of sets and diversities. The upgrade station allows all early gear to stay relevant if one choose to upgrade them. 

Looking forward to future updates. Hoping they remove uncessary bottlenecking or change them in a way that is less annoying. 

Example, Cattle should give the materials right away, Then go on a cooldown. Instead of feeding them, waiting 10 mintues then getting the item.

It can be OK as just something relaxing to mess around with. But if you notice that everyone makes near variations of the same castles and cottages, which you very quickly will... well, there's a reason for that. Tiny Glad is very easy to use and good if you want something to completely autopilot on, but FlowScape easily takes the cake on flexibility (while still being [i]pretty[/i] easy) and variety, if you want to be just a touch more artsy.

Also, personal nitpick with Tiny Glade: The blue "night" lighting is way too intense. Wish you could change it. Or just go very dark to set up some chiaroscuro.

Tiny Glade: A Soothing Escape into Creative Tranquility.


A Personal Journey into Peaceful Creativity:

From the moment I launched Tiny Glade, I felt as though I'd stepped into a serene oasis far removed from the hustle and bustle of daily life. Developed by the indie studio Pounce Light, this game isn't just about building structures—it's about building moments of peace and allowing your imagination to wander freely.


Visual Poetry in Motion:

The game's visuals are nothing short of enchanting. The hand-crafted art style feels warm and inviting, like flipping through the pages of a beautifully illustrated storybook. Each element, from the gently swaying trees to the softly glowing windows of a cottage, is rendered with such care that it’s impossible not to feel a sense of wonder. I often found myself pausing just to watch the way the sunlight filtered through the leaves or how the shadows danced across the rolling hills.


Embracing the Freedom to Create:

What sets Tiny Glade apart is its emphasis on unstructured creativity. There are no timers ticking down or resources to hoard—just an open canvas waiting for your touch. The grid-free building system felt incredibly liberating. I could effortlessly draw a winding stone wall that morphed seamlessly into a quaint archway or let a cobblestone path meander through a meadow without constraints.

At one point, I started constructing a small village nestled at the edge of a forest. As I added little details—a lantern here, a flowerbed there—the place began to feel alive. It was as if the game was encouraging me to tell my own story without uttering a single word.


An Auditory Hug:

The sound design is like a gentle hug for your ears. The soft rustle of leaves, distant bird songs, and the occasional whisper of the wind combined to create a soundscape that was both relaxing and rejuvenating. The music is subtle, never overpowering the experience, but always enhancing the mood.

Reflections on User Experience:

Navigating through Tiny Glade is a breeze. The intuitive controls allowed me to focus on creating rather than fumbling with mechanics. There was a moment when I accidentally erased a section of my build, and instead of feeling frustrated, I found that the game's forgiving nature turned it into an opportunity to try something new. It's rare to find a game that so seamlessly blends user-friendliness with depth.


The Joy of Unwinding:

In a world where games often demand so much from us—be it quick reflexes, strategic thinking, or constant vigilance—Tiny Glade is a welcome reprieve. It's a space where you can slow down, take a deep breath, and let your mind wander.


Final Thoughts:

Tiny Glade isn't just a game; it's an experience—a gentle reminder of the joy found in simplicity and creativity. It rekindles that childlike wonder we often lose along the way. Whether you're an avid gamer looking for something different or someone who simply wants a peaceful escape, Tiny Glade offers a sanctuary worth visiting.

[b]Intro:[/b]
[i]I am a seasoned gamer, I played from A to Z, hundreds and even more hundreds of games since the '90, I know my games and am proud of it. I saw this game, a few days ago, thought it looked nice, relaxing; I saw it had a demo and that its full release wasn't far away. I got immediately hooked, Elden Ring style, but without the frustration and concentration factor, replaced with utter calmness, peace of mind.[/i]

[b]Review(?):[/b]
The game itself is as easy as formidable, it delivers in what it wants you to do and what you actually want to do.
I'm no architect, but I managed to create little scenarios that made me chuckle as I was astonished by how beautiful and cute everything looked; every time I am done and happy with the results of that session, I take screenshots.
You could include "Background Creator" in the game's tags, because they are so gorgeous and "soft" that it calms you just by looking at a picture of something you created, out of literally nothing.

-Having the possibility to play a demo is a major up: every game should give you this opportunity before buying.

-The price is.. great, I was afraid to find 30-40-50 euros at its release, but they stayed true to what the game is; it's easy to find games that cost double and triple of this one and aren't this memorable nowadays, so thank you for that.

-No crash has ever happened, not in the full release nor the demo. I locked it at 60fps, render scale at 1.1 having my pc's performance set quite low so to not make it work, practically at all. Increasing the render scale increases the impact on your pc by a lot, can't say why as I have quite good specs. Upping the render scale to "just" 2.0 squashes my fps to around 20, but I'm using my pc in, almost, sleep mode. If you have problems with performance, lower the render scale by 0.1 until you're happy, it will still look good.

-I've read some reviews that say how this game is lacking in content, that they played a couple dozen minutes and "finished it", to that I can just say that they aren't made for this kind of games and that would be ok if they would say so. Not recommending a game that isn't in your alley, and not specifying it, is in my opinion, wrong. You could play hundreds of hours and not get tired (please not consecutively); the content is in your head. I just put a window on corner of a tower-like square building, then I put a second, and a third, at the end I had a section of the tower converted into a 360° window, it all worked so good and naturally that I stopped and thought what a great job the devs made, because they did.

-Sometimes it's "hard" to start without nothing, but if you continue you'll be amazed by the results; the glades start with something already pre-built, to give you an idea and the daily "challenge" is great for a quick session where you continue something, I presume, they created for the occasion.

[b]Verdict:[/b]
A cute and relaxing building/city builder that gives you the reins to your imagination (in this context of course).
Enough content for as long as your imagination is fresh and trained, or you're willing to let go for a while and just click away; there's a start, but no end.
I am sure they'll add even more nice content, decorations, not for us to place individually, but seamlessly attack to what is around it (tables and chair on a flat roof for example), maybe more wall designs; I'm very confident they'll continue to work on it, and deliver.

It's a [b]9/10[/b] for me, it is just that beautiful and meets its promises like no other game lately.
[i]Bra jobbat, Pounce Light.[/i]

game_genres: Adventure, Casual, Simulation, Free To Play
review_text:
Sims is not a game I would recommend for everybody. Unlike one and two that had stronger story narratives and the building was more secondary: four has the same problem (or advantage depending on your preferred style of gameplay) as three in that the story narrative is hardly there although in four it is more apparent. 
They really made this version for players that enjoy treating it like a sandbox with some minor challenges. A lot of the challenges are very simple unless you're very much not used to that gameplay or just want to create as much chaos as possible. I would say this is much more like playing dollhouse but for adults (as someone who enjoyed playing dollhouse as a kid this is much more of a pro for me). Building, decorating, and creating narratives for your Sims is pretty much the gameplay.
The base game does enough if you want to scratch that itch for a little while, but if you love it and want to play often as a comfort game then you want to invest in some of the DLC. The DLC is the real money makers for the developers and some packs are great, some mid, and a few pretty terrible. Most aren't worth the initial price so wait for a seasonal sale. They usually have a couple sales throughout the year. If you're not sure about the pack then go on Youtube! Sims has a very large and dedicated fanbase! I do recommend lilsimsie since I find her reviews to be less biased and the community is more positive. I have yet to install mods in this version since I find most of the packs I've installed to be enough for me, but I would check out the mods for fun stuff for free. Altogether it can be a really fun game, but it is kind of niche. Also checkout the gallery for fun builds! Whenever I want inspiration then I checkout the community gallery and YT for help. Hope this helps!

game_genres: Adventure, Casual, Simulation, Free To Play
review_text:
This game means a lot to me, and let my playtime tell you that. But I just can't support a game that's being driven through the ground with such horrendous management by the developers. For as long as I've played TS4, almost every update has introduced subtle, major, or even game-breaking glitches. The patches to fix these glitches only add more glitches. The quality control is abysmal, and so are the greedy ambitions to chuck out empty DLC at ridiculously inflated prices.

EA is killing the Sims franchise, and their past actions and future plans are proof of that. If you want a fulfilling Sims experience, play The Sims 3. Unlike TS4, that game isn't free... but also, unlike TS4, it's actually worth it.

game_genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Free To Play
review_text:
Been playing this game for years now, so here are my 2 cents on the game for new players.

This game is hard, like vary hard, if you are new you will die a lot to older players.  So here are a few things you can do to get better at the game.

1. Don't cheat.  You will not get better if you do cheat and you will make the game worse by doing so.
2. Listen to your surroundings.  This can make you win or loss a game just because you could not hear where the other players shots are coming from so you put your back towards the player shooting at you instead of facing them.
3. Do not land at popular sites, this is an easy and fast way to go back to the lobby, instead look for locations at least 1km from where the plane is flying and go there.
4. Play with friends and use VOIP.  You can use the in game VOIP, but what I use is Discord.
5. Don't go more then 100 m from your team mates.  This way when one of you is in trouble, 3 of your team mates are at positions to aid you.  Also don't be to close to each other, as this makes you easier to spot and makes it harder for you and your team mates to return fire when you are in a fire fight.
6. When you see someone, ping them so your team mates know where they are and can aid it taking them down.
7. Take a automatic weapon and a long range weapon (DMR or SR).  My suggestion for a new player is a SMG and a DMR.  For SMG use one of the 3, UMP, VECTOR, MP5K.  As for DMR's, use SLR or DRAGUNOV.
8. Carry at least 4 First Aid kits, 10 bandages, and 4 boosts.
9. Carry 2-3 Smoke grenades.
10. Just have fun.

review_text: The player who uses the perspective cheating function cheats by reporting the location to his teammates. When the player is killed, he can only report the cheating teammate but not the cheater. He can only enter the spectator mode after the whole team dies. However, the cheating team often leaves one member of our team unkilled, making it impossible for the player to spectate the cheating team and accurately find the perspective cheater.

I'll mostly just be reinforcing what many of the other reviews are saying. This is not Frostpunk 1, but bigger and better. This is a new game, with the same setting, similar themes are atmosphere, etc., but this is a new game. I like this new game, others may not. I don't recommend simply buying this because you liked Frostpunk 1. Look at this like it's a fresh game and ask yourself if it looks like the kind of game for you.

And I don't think any of this is a problem. It's not like it's totally disconnected from Frostpunk 1. They wanted to take a crack at it from a totally different angle. Power to them. I wish more games companies did things like this. Take risks, try new ideas, see what happens. Easier said than done, of course.
Amazing sequel

A proper sequel. Takes everything from the first to a more grand scale. Abstracts away 'wood vs iron', for instance, in favor of factions and a council where laws are proposed and deals are made. Loving the gold accents in the menu and visuals. Soundtrack is gas. Yet these are only icing on the already delicious post-apocalyptic society-builder cake.

The game takes great strides to make things feel personal, as in how individuals in your society respond to events and feel. This, despite many reviewers claiming that they feel disconnected from individual workers, for example. My opinion is that what these reviewers want is another Frostpunk expansion, and that's fine. Just don't miss out on this incredibly well done sequel.
