Masterpiece. Game of the year for me.

I didn't play the first one, but heard much about it. So I'm not comparing it to anything, but to me this game is a masterclass in immersion and natural as well as guided storytelling. The mechanics are great and feel different from other games. It's original. The game doesn't hold your hand, the prologue serves as a tutorial, but doesn't feel like a tutorial: You're immediately fighting for survival, but the game never feels unfair. Here and there I wished the consequences of my actions were clearer, but you can always reload, and I suggest making multiple saves. I never got soft locked, but I'm sure you can.

You explore the world as you explore mechanics and the story unfolds. The story feels very authentically interlinked with what you do. When factions were mad at me, they had good reason to, and they all have reasonable stances, that just happen to conflict very often. Moral choices are nuanced.

You will be managing and balancing dozens of things at the same time, have to make sacrifices, sometimes heavy ones, but you always have clear and realistic short and long-term goals. Some self-imposed, some from the game's plot, and some just to keep your people alive and if possible, happy. For a city management game it's extremely exciting. Oftentimes I barely scraped by.

Other developers can learn from this. How to trust your audience: show them the basic with more show than tell, then throw them into the cold water and let them figure it out.

Special shout out to the the graphics and sound design. It's actually a very pretty game and I wish I could zoom in more (the zoom-in on generators doesn't do it for me).

Now that I finished the campaign I can't wait to play the sandbox mode, which seems pretty fleshed out with 7 starting locations and completely different factions from story mode.

Usually when you hear about a sequel its a toss up between "here we go again" or a "Wow! They really improved it." What the devs did with Frostpunk 2 is revamp the game to be almost a new game. 

You feel the constant pressure of your choices. Everything is on the brink of collapse as you try to balance the politics, failing machinery, and ever encroaching cold with resources that are few and far and between. This truly feels like a "survival, post-apocalyptic setting". You desperately need more food, you finally find some frozen food stores under the ice. So you go to build an extraction district to try and pull the resources out. Some of the workforce mining the coal out of the ice died from starvation or the frost. Now you do not have enough workers. So you pull from another area. Some of the children start to go feral as the city starts to descend into anarchy. The coal mine is not producing coal as it dries up, so your generator holding the cold barely at bay is running out of fuel now.  You make a deal with a colony for some of their oil to keep the heat on for a little longer. In doing so, one of the rising factions in the city begins to oppose you because they do not like the deal you made. 

Its a constant struggle of back and forth that makes you feel you are really on the precipice of extinction and about to go over. 
Game play is outstanding. Graphics and audio are great. Some audio sound bite loops (such as when you click on one of the factions) can get old fast. Minor nitpicking aside, this game is absolutely fantastic. No you do not need to buy the first game at all. This is well worth the 45 bucks to a somewhat small studio for game play that is infinitely better than any of the sludge the "AAA" studios will ever produce.

tldr; Good base of a game, wait for some patches to come out and fix the QoL issues. If there was a neutral rating I would give it. There is a good core of the game here, keeping much of the spirit of the first game.There is a good core of the game here, keeping much of the spirit of the first game.

Pros 
1 - Game looks great. Good atmosphere and art on the menus. Colors and well done to lean into the overall dystopia steam punk vibe. 

2 - More of a natural society progression. You don't just get to choose what society you'll be with a simple choice. Your laws, the factions you favor and your choices in events grow your society. This leads to tech and law unlocks. Makes for a fun RP experience and something refreshing to see in a city builder.

3 - Most of the core mechanics of the first game are intact, so resources and heat management especially are still very much the priority.  

4 - Game still has a great soundtrack and atmosphere all around.

Neutral 

1 -  It's on a larger scale than the first game so you don't build individual buildings, you just build districts. Your ascetic control of your colony is basically non-existent. For me this is irksome, but this really comes down to a personal preference. I miss being able to craft my colony to look a certain way. But this is purely an ascetic issue and I can't knock the game for it. 

Cons 

1 - This game should have an early access tag. It has several small bugs that can really just kill your run. You'll spend some amount of time online trying to figure out what happened until you realize it's a bug.
                - Example - First scenario in new london, you establish a colony for oil. My progress just stopped even with ample frost teams. I paused all other outpots to get more frost teams, that did not restart progress. When I sent people to establish the colony, it reduce the number of works in all my buildings in new london. This caused me to have less frost teams. Even after increasing worker count, my colony would not progress in building. Had to reload. Seems like a minor bug, but annoying because if you don't catch it right away it can kill your run.


2 - QoL is poor. Resource management is an integral part of this game. Everything is a slider when it comes to resources, being workers or raw materials. Some you can get precise numbers on because the slider also has small button allowing 1 quantity changes. Others do not have this option, because reasons. So you sometimes have exact control over how many workers are somewhere, or how many resources you send/receive. Other times you just get to throw a handful of workers at a new colony and hope it's close enough to the number you want. Also you can't scroll with arrow key, or middle mouse with the sliders either. Just click and hold. You also can't cancel buildings in progress, and if you lay a building down wrong have to just deal with it later. You also while planning to build, can only cancel in sequential order. Can't click on a tile to cancel just one and build somewhere else. Minor issue but again, just more lifting for the user for seemingly no reason. 

3 - UI is bad, like all form over function bad. You can hotkey to most important things, which is fine. You can also hover over your resources and most of the numbers up top to see a better breakdown. But the idea to have the 5 categories hang below your top UI not really be intractable at all is baffling to me. The worse they get, the longer the tail they get, which can end up cluttering the top of your screen. You also get zero information about them. Some are derived stats, some are all ready covered in your resource needs. They feel redundant and don't serve much purpose beyond the look. You also cannot short cut most actions in a district. It has an empty building slot? Well can't click on the building slot to do anything. Have to exit looking at the district, go to your buildings build menu which is different from your district build menu, find the right sub category for the building you want, then select it. Seems like a minor gripe but like...you can't build any of the buildings outside of their specific district type besides heat ones. Why do they need their own menu, why can they not be done from the district menu? They're upgrades, not independent items. Game becomes more dependent on pause with small things like this. 

4 - Game is gonna chug after you set up some colonies and managing more than one city. Needs some performance optimization.
Lots of Snow! Two Frostbitten Thumbs Up!

Good as the first game

The game looks very nice in terms of graphics, but they tried to innovate on too many new mechanics, way too diversified from the first Frostpunk, and for me they clearly failed. It's very unpolished; they just tried to implement on top of the old version, but it feels and plays way worse. They tried to overcomplicate it with fancy menus and choices with 100 drop-down menus; it just feels like they put all these things in there just to have more options without thinking about the fun in the game, like the first one. It just feels like a mess; there is no clear way to describe it, but coming from over 142.8 hours in the first game, this feels like a different Frostpunk game... Sad, but maybe I expected too much to be like the first game and just be better (upgraded).

Frostpunk 2's user interface feels overly complicated and cluttered compared to the streamlined design of the first game. The shift away from the neatness of the original makes it difficult to understand what’s happening at times, with too much filler content. Some research options appear across multiple tabs, causing confusion, and there’s a noticeable lack of quality-of-life features like the ability to cancel construction. Additionally, heat continues to be consumed even when a district is turned off, which feels counterintuitive. The six-slot district system seems like a questionable design choice, though it’s not my main issue. While I love the direction the game has taken, the execution feels lacking, with clutter and disorganisation detracting from the experience.

Frostpunk 2 does justice to the original while bringing some interesting new game play. Overall it emphasizes a macro approach, with the overall scale of "The City" and its inhabitants dialed all the way up. The population count is higher, there are more resource/types, you can create and maintain more than one city/settlement during a run, and the faction system is dynamic. I do miss the small scale of Frostpunk 1 at times. Starting off with a handful of settlers and watching them trudge throw snow and ice, some freezing to death, in a desperate effort to collect enough coal and other resources to survive. Frostpunk 2s larger scale results in not experiencing or witnessing your citizens in the same way, but overall there can be no doubt Frostpunk 2 will be a successful sequel.

While I very much enjoy the game, I still have very mixed feelings about it. The change in scale from the original, as others have pointed out, makes things a bit less impactful. I find myself going, "well, that's the cost of doing business" way too much.
However, my biggest issue is that, despite the delayed release, the game really could've benefited from another few months in the oven to polish off some of the more obvious bugs. For example, I've encountered a few weird UI glitches. That's to say nothing of the day-1 patch "temporary fix" for what is a pretty jarring audio crackling issue in big cities. It's not a good look to release it like this.

Please, developers, and I mean all game developers, not just 11-Bit Studios: Polish off your games. People will forgive less obvious bugs, but when you release a game with glaring issues that *had* to have been apparent prior to release, it's really bad form. Day-1 patches for these kinds of issues don't really mitigate the optics, in my book. Day-1 patches say to me, "we know the game isn't finished, but we're releasing it anyway."

In conclusion, this is a tentative "not recommended" from me, purely on the grounds of it being released without solving the aforementioned obvious bugs. I'm confident these issues will be fixed soon, but the game being released in this state leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

I was disappointed starting at 'build district' and it hasn't gotten better. It's Frostpunk minus the charm, grit, and detail that made the first game so excellent. If I was new to the franchise and you told me this was the first game and the original was Frostpunk 2, I'd believe it.
if your buying this because you enjoyed FP1, understand your not buying the same game. I'm having a difficult time getting into FP2, its very different, too different imo.

Overall, I did enjoy this game. It does feel like a natural progression from Frostpunk 1, in terms of scale. In both games, resource management is important and have far-reaching consequences if you do not manage it well. I do agree with some reviews that in Frostpunk 2, you don't feel as attached to the individuals when compared to Frostpunk 1. People, at least to a degree, are just numbers. But I did enjoy the statements from individual characters in the game in general. However, when I finished the main story, I wouldn't help but wonder if I did my best, or whether I did the right thing. All I could say was an attempt was made. I would argue there was an emotional attachment involved in Frostpunk 2, but not to the individual. Rather, I felt more attached to the city itself. Achieving that isn't easy and I do applaud 11-Bit Studios for taking a risk here. The game did do a good job at making things feel desperate near the end but I do admit, the music wasn't as noticeable for some reason.

Overall I did like the game, but I am not sure I liked this game as much as Frostpunk 1. I really do enjoy the lore however.

As a fan of Crusader Kings II, I was excited to try Crusader Kings III, and it did not disappoint. The mechanics have been refined and expanded, making the game even more immersive. My first campaign was a wild ride, and I loved it.

I started as Duchess Matilda of Tuscany, and things quickly went out of control. After committing the "crime" of fornication, I had to deal with the consequences not once, but twice: first, when the child was born, and then when someone blackmailed me to reveal the father’s identity. I refused. My liege, Kaiser Heinrich IV of the Holy Roman Empire, decided to arrest me twice, ruining my reputation and legitimacy. To make matters worse, he revoked some of my titles, reducing me from a Duchess to a Countess.

I plotted an assassination scheme against the Kaiser, and to my surprise, it worked. With a new liege, I set my sights on recovering my lost titles. I declared war on my Duke and, after a tense battle, managed to reclaim two of them. While I didn't get back all of my original titles (I went from 6 down to 4), it was still a lot of fun.

By the end of Matilda's life, she held 10 titles. It was an unexpected journey, but that’s what makes the game so enjoyable, you never quite know where things will end up.

The reasons I'm recommending this probably differ from that of a lot of other players. (My total playing hours are over 100 by the way but started on a different clock).

The reasons are in two categories, (a) the unexpected playability factor and (b) the medieval simulator factor.

A - Playability - Paradox have finally found the sweet spot between complexity and accessibility. I did not come to CK3 with much hope of enjoying it, much less being any good at it. I say that because I've struggled and indeed given up on other Paradox games, finding them intimidating, the learning curve too steep, decision paralysis etc. Somehow with CK3 Paradox has finally nailed the combination of deploying myriad extremely deep and complex mechanics, but making them (just) accessible enough to get into. It's like you can put your toe in the shallow end and gradually wade in until the game consumes you. I've also learned enough from my first playthrough of CK3 that I feel like now I can take another look at those other Paradox games I'd given up on (looking at you, EU4....) because I now feel like I understand much more of the fundamentals and meta-mechanics of a Paradox grand strategy game that I simply couldn't wrap my head around until CK3.

That is NOT to say CK3 is "easy" or "simple". Far from it...it's a deep and rewarding game that also manages to capture the 'just one more turn' addictiveness of the Civilization series despite it being real-time (with pause at will), not turn based. That is a massive hat-tip and compliment from me.

How does Paradox manage to bring the 'just one more turn' impulse to a real-time grand strategy game? Read on for the next category:

B - A medieval simulator: This game memorably recreates the sheer chaos and unpredictability of medieval history by simulating how the smallest event can set of a chain of instability that brings carefully laid plans to ruin...and then stunning reversals to reclaim glory from ashes.

The game gives life to the old saying 'for want of a nail, the Kingdom was lost...' because seemingly insignificant relationships, events, minor misdeeds can suddenly cascade into realm-wide catastrophe....but it's neither random nor "unfair"...one can experience how everyday events had real-world consequences on a massive scale during this incredible period of history.

CK3 has done what no other Paradox game could...got me playing, enjoying it, and keeping on for 'just one more turn'...!

Having loved Crusader Kings II, I went into CK3 with high hopes. After spending a good amount of time with the game, I can say that while I like Crusader Kings III, I’ll never feel as excited about it as I was with its predecessor. The leap from CK2 to CK3 feels minor in terms of gameplay evolution — outside of the graphical improvements, the core mechanics haven’t been significantly expanded upon.

Unfortunately, the major issue that plagued CK2, namely repetitiveness, hasn't been adequately addressed. There are moments of brilliance, and it's still a fun game for those who enjoy grand strategy, but it lacks the depth and novelty to keep me as engaged as CK2 did over the years.

If you’re new to the series, CK3 is a solid place to start. But for veterans of CK2, the experience may feel more familiar than fresh.

I got some hours into the game. It's a hard game to get bored of.  Just not the factions are different from each other, so are the lords within those factions. There are enough DLC's, free content, and updates to keep the gave fresh. 

The journey of the game was different from most franchises since in some respects, each Warhammer can be considered one big DLC. I say this as a positive, because it makes the world massive and gives a great of variety of different play throughs. 

The meat of the game isn't the campaign(s), it's "Immortal Empires" the game mode that brings all games together. However I do hope one day they do make a final campaign or even a game mode where it's the forces of "good" vs "Evil" working together.
This is, quite possibly, the best game I've ever played... But I wouldn't reccomend it due to the scummy pricing, and having to buy older games and dlcs to even use most of the factions.
It's total war, in the WH universe. Cool units, neat maps, so many items and abilities for lords and heros.

This installment of Total War has been the best one by far, in my opinion, having some of the most interesting combat, Lords, Heroes and Unit rosters per Faction. Albeit, they had some issues with some of the DLC they still made a great game.

Over the years, between the 3 games I have 5150 hrs, that's approximately 215 days of play. I think thats a resounding YES! And/or a caution that you can lose yourself in this fantasy world. 

The "price gauging" is an industry thing, not specific to this game but it did lead to a massive review bomb here. The dev's have responded admirably to that and have made noticeably positive changes to their roadmap. The current situation stands "Here's some DLC. If you're interested in some or all, pay for want you want." Considering the time and effort that goes into this, + the recent dev dives for the future, I dont think the "mixed reviews" mean anything any more. 

The Workshop enabled mod scene adds almost infinite replayability to this game.

100% YES, What are you waiting for?
Pretty huge game, but way too expensive with all the DLC factions. Only buy the Trilogy Warhammer bundle when on sale if you want to own the whole map and get all the base factions like I did.

Really comes down to if you'll enjoy what you're paying for. 

23 dlcs (a # that will only go up in the coming months) AND you have to own the previous installations to access their respective base factions. You'd have to be insane or rich to not buy anything here on sale. 

I'm going to recommend the game because I consider it worthwhile for what I paid for. It's a nice battle simulator even if you're not familiar with Warhammer. However, you must do your homework to see if this is the game for you.

Considering I played both Persona 4 and 5 before this my hopes were quite high for this game and i can say it was actually way better than i thought it'd be.

Persona 3 considering its the oldest of the three (story wise) it feels like a breath of fresh air as i feel both persona 4 and 5 kinda follow the same kind of trend. Especially when it comes to the cast i feel as when it comes to the *best friend character* in persona games he's pretty stock standard. However, when it came to persona 3 Junpei felt like an actual realistic best friend, sure he still likes you as a friend but I like the fact there were many times in the story where he was extremely jealous of the mc, and then the way they tackled his meaning for living was very well done easily making Junpei one of my favourite characters in the game. 

The story was extremely good with many highs and many lows for the cast I'd honestly love to see a game that follows a similar path to persona 3 rather than 4 or 5, (not to say i dont like 4 or 5).

The only complaint i had is tartarus often felt quite repetitive and most the bosses just seemed almost like filler bosses.

I give this a 9/10 very good would recommend :D

The game that got me into Megami Tensei all those years ago beautifully remade.

Persona 3 Portable was the first Persona game I ever played, and even after experiencing all the others, it remains my favorite. I was really surprised when they announced a remake of Persona 3, as I had never played the original. So, this was technically my first time seeing the game in a 3D environment.

While the remake lacks the Female Protagonist from P3P, as many people have pointed out, which does make me sad, I do somewhat understand why she was ultimately scrapped. Even though she's not included, I still think this game is worth buying, as it made me cry even more than the P3P version ( which was a lot ), despite already knowing what would happen in the story.

The new features added to the remake, such as Shifting and the Linked Episodes—especially for Shinjiro and Ryoji—are a very welcome change. The new Strega scenes also help give the group more importance and plot significance. Overall, I'm so glad this remake came out, and I can't wait to see what's next for the Persona series. Whether it's Persona 6 or another remake, we'll just have to wait and see.

Definitely really tried to like this game. The art and music is amazing, but the game is EXTREMELY grindy. 

The game definitely feels like it doesn't respect your time with a fairly large map that takes awhile to move around in. Making things such as a minecart network feels like a hassle, since mine carts  / boats aren't equipped to your character, but placed on the rail network, so if you die, you'll have to walk all the way back to get your vehicle.  Fast travel points are few and far between, and the only way (As far as I know) to create an additional fast travel point is extremely resource intensive and has a TEN minute cooldown.

You'll also need a large amount of materials for a lot of stuff in the game, which the game seems to flirt with automating the process a bit by having automated drills to get these resources for you.  The way you can automate things is extremely basic however, and will require you to just randomly explore until you find an appropriate node you can place your drills at. 

The gearing for combat in this game also feels pretty basic, and doesn't have as much synergies as I'd like. For example, I equipped an armour set that increases crit chance upon poisoning an enemy. However I found that this trait doesn't proc when using a range weapon that poisons enemies, when using a character skill that inflicts poison whenever you deal damage, or when using a pet that poisons enemies. It seems to only proc when using a poison melee weapon - which wasn't mentioned in the description of the armour set. 

The breaking point for me in this game was [spoiler] A large underwater sea section, which you basically need a boat for traveling around at. There's a water boss in this section without a fast travel point near it. Dying to it not only means having to make the long trek back, but you'll either need to remake your really expensive boat or make a long land bridge back to your stuff[/spoiler]

Ultimately, I was looking for something to scratch my survival crafting itch, but there's not enough here to justify the massive grind.

I have never been into 2d games, I have never been into civ building, I have never been into indie games. 

And I love this! Time flies when you are playing this.

I did a full play through with a friend in a single seed to 100% the game in a little over 120 hours.  The progression of this game is fantastic and the crafting system is easy to use/follow.  Go-karts, Boating, PvE, PVP, boss battles... I was never bored playing this game as there is always something to do.  The customization you are allowed to make in game is endless (painting, flooring, walls, farming, automation, mob spawning, etc.).  Essentially you need to defeat certain bosses to gather parts to power the core, which will unlock more of the available map.  There are also optional bosses, ALL of which have fun mechanics and I recommend trying all boss fights.  The appearance of the game to me was appealing, giving almost a retro feel to the game.  This game felt like it took great aspects from other games I've played and put it into one. 
 Very fun game, definitely recommend it.  

Things I've learned/tips:
1.)  Using the Map - to place the Icons, select the desired icon and click the middle mouse button on the map to add; click on same spot to remove.  Mark boss fighting/summoning locations to find easier later on.
2.)  If you want to customize flooring that doesn't allow it to be painted; put a "glass floor" on top of it, then paint it.  May find a color you like w/ that pattern.
3.)  Create Scanners to find bosses, sooo much more convenient than blindly running around the map.
4.)  Save the figurines you collect.  There's a way to "power" them to have them spawn that type of mob; they do not drop loot, though still grant exp for your skill ups.
5.)  You have 3 different gear sets, recommend binding those sets to hotkeys.  Some fights may be much easier if/when you switch armor sets/tactics during the fight.

Hope the above helps, enjoy!
Better than WB platform fighter

The game has been super fun. Started with hard mode and it provided enough of a challenge to keep the game interesting. The game provides enough variety of activities to keep you exploring without tiring out from any one activity. When you get tired of fishing, for example, you move on to something else for a while. 

I'm not a min/max kind of player, so I do my own builds with whatever I find via natural play through and was able to find some of the legendary weapons in good time. Ranged weapons are very good in this game, especially physical ranged like the daggers. Overall, Armor sets favor physical melee and ranged builds. There are some for casters or summoners as well, but they aren't very strong end game and fall off fast. Mainly because there are only two books to summon creatures. At some point  the mana cost gets to be too high and the bats are too dumb for combat situations to really focus on summons and I found myself using daggers or other weapons like the fireball staff to compensate. I really really tried making a summoner build work on its own, but I couldn't get through some of the content even though I was geared fairly well. Switched to physical range and beat everything no problem. At the time of me writing this, I have only the remaining two titans left, which I'm about to tackle next. 

Good game and definitely worth playing. Can't wait to see what else they'll add. Hoping that summoners get some more love

40 hrs so far and for the most part, Ive really had a good time. I do feel like the game suffers from an identity crisis. Does it want to be an open world survival like Minecraft, something casual like Stardew Valley, or more of a Boss a Rush type of game?

The postive thing ia that you get a little bit of all 3, but the negative is that you have to deal with game mechanics that intentionally slow you down.

Example, Trying to farm Wool, but you can only do it every 10 real time minutes. Bosses that have a cooldown before they respawn. Or farming for the 3 upgrade materials, Emearld,Ruby, and Sapphire which take forever without a Mob spawner. 

If you can look past the obnoxious grind for materials, I think youll enjoy your stay here. Alot of these materials arent necessary until later in the game depending on how fast you push into the next zone.


Boss are cool. Lots of sets and diversities. The upgrade station allows all early gear to stay relevant if one choose to upgrade them. 

Looking forward to future updates. Hoping they remove uncessary bottlenecking or change them in a way that is less annoying. 

Example, Cattle should give the materials right away, Then go on a cooldown. Instead of feeding them, waiting 10 mintues then getting the item.

Tiny Glade: A Soothing Escape into Creative Tranquility.


A Personal Journey into Peaceful Creativity:

From the moment I launched Tiny Glade, I felt as though I'd stepped into a serene oasis far removed from the hustle and bustle of daily life. Developed by the indie studio Pounce Light, this game isn't just about building structures—it's about building moments of peace and allowing your imagination to wander freely.


Visual Poetry in Motion:

The game's visuals are nothing short of enchanting. The hand-crafted art style feels warm and inviting, like flipping through the pages of a beautifully illustrated storybook. Each element, from the gently swaying trees to the softly glowing windows of a cottage, is rendered with such care that it’s impossible not to feel a sense of wonder. I often found myself pausing just to watch the way the sunlight filtered through the leaves or how the shadows danced across the rolling hills.


Embracing the Freedom to Create:

What sets Tiny Glade apart is its emphasis on unstructured creativity. There are no timers ticking down or resources to hoard—just an open canvas waiting for your touch. The grid-free building system felt incredibly liberating. I could effortlessly draw a winding stone wall that morphed seamlessly into a quaint archway or let a cobblestone path meander through a meadow without constraints.

At one point, I started constructing a small village nestled at the edge of a forest. As I added little details—a lantern here, a flowerbed there—the place began to feel alive. It was as if the game was encouraging me to tell my own story without uttering a single word.


An Auditory Hug:

The sound design is like a gentle hug for your ears. The soft rustle of leaves, distant bird songs, and the occasional whisper of the wind combined to create a soundscape that was both relaxing and rejuvenating. The music is subtle, never overpowering the experience, but always enhancing the mood.

Reflections on User Experience:

Navigating through Tiny Glade is a breeze. The intuitive controls allowed me to focus on creating rather than fumbling with mechanics. There was a moment when I accidentally erased a section of my build, and instead of feeling frustrated, I found that the game's forgiving nature turned it into an opportunity to try something new. It's rare to find a game that so seamlessly blends user-friendliness with depth.


The Joy of Unwinding:

In a world where games often demand so much from us—be it quick reflexes, strategic thinking, or constant vigilance—Tiny Glade is a welcome reprieve. It's a space where you can slow down, take a deep breath, and let your mind wander.


Final Thoughts:

Tiny Glade isn't just a game; it's an experience—a gentle reminder of the joy found in simplicity and creativity. It rekindles that childlike wonder we often lose along the way. Whether you're an avid gamer looking for something different or someone who simply wants a peaceful escape, Tiny Glade offers a sanctuary worth visiting.

[b]Intro:[/b]
[i]I am a seasoned gamer, I played from A to Z, hundreds and even more hundreds of games since the '90, I know my games and am proud of it. I saw this game, a few days ago, thought it looked nice, relaxing; I saw it had a demo and that its full release wasn't far away. I got immediately hooked, Elden Ring style, but without the frustration and concentration factor, replaced with utter calmness, peace of mind.[/i]

[b]Review(?):[/b]
The game itself is as easy as formidable, it delivers in what it wants you to do and what you actually want to do.
I'm no architect, but I managed to create little scenarios that made me chuckle as I was astonished by how beautiful and cute everything looked; every time I am done and happy with the results of that session, I take screenshots.
You could include "Background Creator" in the game's tags, because they are so gorgeous and "soft" that it calms you just by looking at a picture of something you created, out of literally nothing.

-Having the possibility to play a demo is a major up: every game should give you this opportunity before buying.

-The price is.. great, I was afraid to find 30-40-50 euros at its release, but they stayed true to what the game is; it's easy to find games that cost double and triple of this one and aren't this memorable nowadays, so thank you for that.

-No crash has ever happened, not in the full release nor the demo. I locked it at 60fps, render scale at 1.1 having my pc's performance set quite low so to not make it work, practically at all. Increasing the render scale increases the impact on your pc by a lot, can't say why as I have quite good specs. Upping the render scale to "just" 2.0 squashes my fps to around 20, but I'm using my pc in, almost, sleep mode. If you have problems with performance, lower the render scale by 0.1 until you're happy, it will still look good.

-I've read some reviews that say how this game is lacking in content, that they played a couple dozen minutes and "finished it", to that I can just say that they aren't made for this kind of games and that would be ok if they would say so. Not recommending a game that isn't in your alley, and not specifying it, is in my opinion, wrong. You could play hundreds of hours and not get tired (please not consecutively); the content is in your head. I just put a window on corner of a tower-like square building, then I put a second, and a third, at the end I had a section of the tower converted into a 360° window, it all worked so good and naturally that I stopped and thought what a great job the devs made, because they did.

-Sometimes it's "hard" to start without nothing, but if you continue you'll be amazed by the results; the glades start with something already pre-built, to give you an idea and the daily "challenge" is great for a quick session where you continue something, I presume, they created for the occasion.

[b]Verdict:[/b]
A cute and relaxing building/city builder that gives you the reins to your imagination (in this context of course).
Enough content for as long as your imagination is fresh and trained, or you're willing to let go for a while and just click away; there's a start, but no end.
I am sure they'll add even more nice content, decorations, not for us to place individually, but seamlessly attack to what is around it (tables and chair on a flat roof for example), maybe more wall designs; I'm very confident they'll continue to work on it, and deliver.

It's a [b]9/10[/b] for me, it is just that beautiful and meets its promises like no other game lately.
[i]Bra jobbat, Pounce Light.[/i]

game_genres: Adventure, Casual, Simulation, Free To Play
review_text:
Sims is not a game I would recommend for everybody. Unlike one and two that had stronger story narratives and the building was more secondary: four has the same problem (or advantage depending on your preferred style of gameplay) as three in that the story narrative is hardly there although in four it is more apparent. 
They really made this version for players that enjoy treating it like a sandbox with some minor challenges. A lot of the challenges are very simple unless you're very much not used to that gameplay or just want to create as much chaos as possible. I would say this is much more like playing dollhouse but for adults (as someone who enjoyed playing dollhouse as a kid this is much more of a pro for me). Building, decorating, and creating narratives for your Sims is pretty much the gameplay.
The base game does enough if you want to scratch that itch for a little while, but if you love it and want to play often as a comfort game then you want to invest in some of the DLC. The DLC is the real money makers for the developers and some packs are great, some mid, and a few pretty terrible. Most aren't worth the initial price so wait for a seasonal sale. They usually have a couple sales throughout the year. If you're not sure about the pack then go on Youtube! Sims has a very large and dedicated fanbase! I do recommend lilsimsie since I find her reviews to be less biased and the community is more positive. I have yet to install mods in this version since I find most of the packs I've installed to be enough for me, but I would check out the mods for fun stuff for free. Altogether it can be a really fun game, but it is kind of niche. Also checkout the gallery for fun builds! Whenever I want inspiration then I checkout the community gallery and YT for help. Hope this helps!

game_genres: Adventure, Casual, Simulation, Free To Play
review_text:
This game means a lot to me, and let my playtime tell you that. But I just can't support a game that's being driven through the ground with such horrendous management by the developers. For as long as I've played TS4, almost every update has introduced subtle, major, or even game-breaking glitches. The patches to fix these glitches only add more glitches. The quality control is abysmal, and so are the greedy ambitions to chuck out empty DLC at ridiculously inflated prices.

EA is killing the Sims franchise, and their past actions and future plans are proof of that. If you want a fulfilling Sims experience, play The Sims 3. Unlike TS4, that game isn't free... but also, unlike TS4, it's actually worth it.

7/10 if I wanna be critical

I'd say this game is great if you just focus on the main parts of the game and just enjoy your time with what you have.
However, if you want to play stuff that isn't included stock... well, your wallet definitely won't be thanking you any time soon.

The music is pretty good, I'd say for every, "Meh, it's okay," you'll have two, "Dang, that's pretty good." But to get that "WOW" feeling, you better cough up some of your precious dollars. This is because the songs that come with the game seem almost specifically designed to be a level or two below the paid content; not enough to really upset you, but just enough to sort of bug you. This will inevitably lead to you buying at least one of the DLC that you simply don't need. All of that knocks off a good chunk of the out-of-ten score.

If you're okay with spending money on what is, admittedly, a decent variety of songs (even if it's an objectively bad deal), then you'll have a really good experience. It's not just the songs that are better; the mapping is, too. The maps in the base-game are alright, but most of them lack a certain level of enjoyment. The DLC maps fix that, in my opinion, bringing the count of really good or enjoyable maps from 1 in 5 to 1 in 3 (or even 1 in 2). The DLC is definitely high quality from what I've seen.

But don't fret over that high price-tag as I once did. There are plenty of sales throughout each year to really enable your addiction to spending, with packs plummeting from around $30 (CAD) to just $7; sometimes, the prices can get even lower than that, so keep an eye out.

Hope this review helped someone. Thanks for reading :)

[b]DJMAX RESPECT V[/b] is one of the most well-crafted rhythm games I’ve ever played. Every penny spent on it is worth the experience. One of the first things that impressed me was how unique and distinct each theme is, with every theme having its own background music when selecting modes. Each chart has its own music video, and if it doesn’t, the game creates an original one, clearly showing the level of care and investment from the developers.

The game is frequently updated, not only adding new songs but also introducing more difficulty levels to older charts. The game features four modes: 4B, 5B, 6B, and 8B. If you want to "get good," you should play every mode, starting from 4B, then progressing to 6B, and so on.

In terms of value, if you're lucky enough to buy the game and its DLCs during a sale, it’s a steal. I was able to get the full game at 80% off.

My only minor complaint is that the game doesn’t have many collaborations with other major rhythm games. While Chunithm and Muse Dash are included, I’d love to see DJMAX RESPECT V collaborate with games like maimai or SDVX and feature more Japanese artists. However, I have to admit that the game already offers a diverse range of music for everyone. I’m not a big fan of K-pop, but DJMAX changed my mind. I got to know more lesser-known Korean artists like TAK, KATOMORI, and XeoN, and I must say, I’m really addicted to their music.

DJMAX RESPECT V truly offers an arcade-like experience at home. [b]Solid 10/10[/b].

This is a go-to comfort game for me. Originally, I first played it on Switch, and despite having no idea what I was doing it was very calming and relaxing, so I didn't feel pressured to play a certain way. Now, it's the game I suggest to play with friends who aren't as familiar with gaming because of its laidback nature. Personally, I love planting my crops and befriending the villagers, but there are so many wonderful aspects to explore, and its overall simplicity (that does get more complex the further you dive in the game) is what makes it so endearing. Stardew Valley has the balance of characterization, farming, mining, fishing, mystery, and more, but its the love and devotion that has gone into its creation that has cemented it in a corner of my heart. I cannot recommend it enough.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!

It's so strange I find myself having a hard time describing why I love this game due to there being so many reasons, but I'm gonna try anyways lol

The World of Cyberpunk 2077 is a dark and gritty one. A dystopian but but also real future where you're either rich or barely surviving. but what makes this game beautiful is, despite it all, you keep fighting for a better life, never fully loosing hope even at your lowest of lows. the game shows this with not only your character but also the supporting cast. Characters who often seem hard and tuff like the city has forced them to be opening up to you and being vurnurable to you as you get to know them. Judy, Panam, heck even Johnny Silverhand. all characters who I will remember and cherish.

Now as to the gameplay when this game first came out it was, and I pardon my language, Dogshit... But ever since the 2.0 update they overhauled everything and somehow did a complete 180! With the gunplay going from feeling unimpactful and bland to OOMPHY in the best way possible and then the upgrade system acually feeling worth it with new abilities and customization to make truly unique and fun builds all of which are viable! I personaly love fully upgrading reflexes allowing me to dash and dodge around both on ground and mid-air for some really fun almost bullethell like movement or going for a more stealth build allowing you to quickly take out enemy bases and finish gigs with a quick swipe reall assassin style! just a few of the many ways to play the game and I can practically garantee that there is a playstyle for you! So much fun.

The music is also amazing and somethign I wanna highlight as a producer myself. It really perfected what Cyberpunk should sound like. It's drone like nature with these elements of punk music really fusing together in such a unique way! It just has this tensity to it that just feels suspenseful. Then there's the action music which I swear I would be so much stealthier if it didn't go as hard as it goes cuz DAMN it makes me pumped! It's so intense and adrenaline filled and fits so well to every senario! truly spectacular.
but the best tracks in the game for me are the more quiet ones. the ones that play in somber or joyful moments. the themes of the characters you meet. Johnnys theme using a cello/violin making it sound like a guitar somehow is just beautiful and really shows another side of johnny in a way. and leidmotives of "never fade away" (a song by Johnnys band) playing at just the right times making it almost a theme of sorts for the events that it plays in. I dunno It just adds so much to the imersion and I can't get enough of it.

And don't even get me started on the DLC. Phantom Liberty is one of the best expansions I have ever played. The district of Dogtown is dense and full of fun activities to do, but once again the highlights are the characters. Somehow they're even deeper than before, feeling like acual people who all have unique motives and personalities that when it came time to choose I couldn't decide cuz I cared so much for all of them. I wanted the best for all of them but due to the nature of the story (which i won't spoil) I could'nt and it was heartbreaking, but it also felt beautiful in a way. Just absolutly phenomenal story telling and a story I will never forget.

In the end I would personally highly recommend this game. It's a game I always come back to replay, a world that I can't get enough of and one of those games that gave me something I'll keep for the rest of my life. It might take some time to get into but trust me once ur in it will be an experience you will never forget. an experience that, despite it's dark nature, made me feel hope. A thing of beauty for sure.

and a thing of beauty will never fade away...

Cyberpunk 2077 is an action-rpg set in a future where corporations a locked in a struggle for domination over the scraps of the old world left behind by cataclysmic wars, Rogue AIs and a captured, decadent, and complicit populace.
The main story is staged in Night City, an open-world sandbox with a mix of neo-noir and ganster movie characters and narratives. While the DLC's is significantly smaller in scope, it's a tight, well written spy thriller that keeps some of the same beats (the heist elements) but remains fresh with new stakes and an interesting cast.
The RPG is well implemented: in addition to "cyberware" -interchangeable parts that influence your controls, movements patterns, weapon affinity and some gameplay interactions, you have 3 main variables that make for very deep character building: Attributes, Perks and Skills.
You have 5 main Attributes- each Attributes will have its own "Perk" tree. Raising an Attribute (up to a max of 20) will unlock more (and better) Perks. Attributes mostly have an influence on weapon proficiency and some interactions, but will also impact how you approach certain missions. Will you break the door? Can you hack the door? Can you stay hidden or will you ram through? The 3D environment of Night City helps you tackle situations with a wide variety of possible solutions.
While the "Attributes" can only be reset once per game, the Perks can be refunded and distributed again as many times as you wish outside combat, encouraging experimentation. You can see which weapons work best for you, how your perks interact with each other and your cybernetic implants.
The Skills progress naturally- anytime you perform an action, take down an enemy with a certain weapon, pass a dialogue or Attribute check- the related Skill will increase. Up to a max of 50, every 5 levels you will unlock a permanent boost.

I think the main downside to the game is how long it is- not all missions are created equal and sometimes it's a drag or a bit of a bore, but those moments are few and sandwiched between thrilling combat sequence. Didn't particularly care for the DB elements either.

Overall 9/10, the few narrative lapses or repetitive nature of some missions didn't spoil my fun enough to bring the score lower than that. I would just add that the soundtrack is a constant banger and is very serviceable to the story.

I didn’t expect to like this game. As an old-school Diablo 2 fan, I was skeptical, but with all the hype and seeing it on sale, I decided to give it a try. Somehow, the game sucks you in. It’s like watching grandma at the casino—every slot machine is hitting. Some of the payouts are pennies, and some are much bigger, but the idea that you might hit big or miss out on the next great item or event keeps you hooked.

There’s a lot of flash and bang, action-packed gore to keep things interesting, and plenty of ways to build your character. You can easily spend hours just sitting at your stash, or googling new ways to improve a single build. I wouldn’t say it’s the best game out there, but it definitely does the job when it comes to keeping you entertained.

I held off on buying this game for a long time because I do not want to support the idea of a battle pass.  I find they often ruin great games.  I eventually gave in and bought this during a trial period and really enjoyed it, so much so that I bought it, despite my grumblings against it.  Since then I've enjoyed it, despite the battle pass, which only has cosmetic rewards.  I still don't love the idea of a battle pass but the fact that the battle pass is purely cosmetic helps water it down for me.  Another thing that helps greatly is that the free tier of armor looks really amazing.  They didn't skimp on armor cosmetics to try and guide people towards buying cosmetics, which is a big plus and actually the only reason I would recommend the game.  As far as game play goes, it's been really fun.  End game is a little complicated and to get anywhere you have to follow someone else's build but that's pretty standard for RPGs these days.

Perfect for the steam deck as long as you have an internet connection. Easy time killer, fun to play and easy to learn. This is my first time playing with this IP and I am having a blast. Starting multiple characters and seeing how they change your playstyle is more fun than I thought it would be and lots of game left even after you've finished the campaign. I would recommend it for someone who likes a strategy game mixed with slaying monsters and creatures from a high 3rd person view style. The visuals are also quite good especially on the steam deck; which is what I buy a lot of games for since I travel a ton. Expansion coming in October as well to continue the story and add new game mechanics, characters and abilities. The only downside I have with this game is that it needs to be connected to the internet the entire time and you can not play offline.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.
One of the Best Story DLCs I've seen in recent years. Loved the story and sat a solid 10 minutes at the end pondering what decisions to make.

An extremely well polished thriller. I was absolutely hooked! As I mentioned in my review of the base game, the decisions you make in the base game and DLC, and their consequences stay in your mind even long after you're done playing the game.

The game is in a very good state now than it was at launch, and I highly recommend playing it now if you didn't back when it launched.

Cyberpunk isn't a good game by any measure and the less of its setting leaks into the real world, the better but if you do end up playing it, get Phantom Liberty and ignore the main game to the best of your ability.
The dlc is its own thing pretty much with an extra ending of its own, which has the added benefit of skipping the remainder of the core vidya.

Now, onto the good things: the script, the pacing, the dialogues, the execution of a properly polished thriller. The DLC adds some extra missions for old fixers. Fetch quests aside, the quest are good too, adding depth and nuance to the NPCs. Though the most important is the selection of end-game choices you're presented with. Between wetwork, dubious loyalties and complex motivations of dramatis personaes, someone did their homework on intelligence services so a lot of it offers a very authentic experience. A lot of times you leave feeling dirty - because that is the nature of the work. My only criticism is you couldn't off Meyers (it'd be tons of fun, I think), but otherwise it's next to excellent. Johnny's dialogue at the end of the lunar escape was a rare gem, diverging from his usual abrasive rants. Meeting Mr Hands in person was somewhat of a letdown, but more gigs from the sphinxian villain was welcome.

It's difficult to believe the DLC was produced by the same studio as the cliché and filth-filled dumpster fire that is the core game. The setting remains as disgusting as ever, with humanity locked in a dull and primitive state of neo-feudal corporate overlords or communes of plain-roaming barbarians, but Phantom Liberty redeems the price tag. If you find a way to skip to the DLC and just play the extra, do it: it is a real treat for any lovers of a spy drama - something Deux Ex tried and failed to do.

Edit: ending credits animation film was an outstanding tribute to the classic James Bond movies. Stellar.

PREEM DLC
It's the best expansion for a single player game ever made, and its not even close. Blood & Wine was amazing, but Phantom Liberty is stunning.
AMAZING

Ah, “Phantom Liberty,” where the neon lights are brighter, the stakes are higher, and the glitches are… well, let’s just say they’re part of the charm. Imagine if James Bond, Keanu Reeves, and Idris Elba decided to throw a party in Night City, and you get to clean up the mess. That’s Phantom Liberty for you.

The expansion kicks off with the President of the New United States crash-landing in Dogtown. Yes, you read that right. Apparently, Air Force One now comes with a “crash here for plot development” button. You’re hired to rescue her, but not before you navigate through a maze of cybernetic baddies, morally ambiguous choices, and enough plot twists to make a pretzel jealous.

Idris Elba’s character, Solomon Reed, is the secret agent we all wish we could be. He’s suave, he’s mysterious, and he probably has a better skincare routine than you. Meanwhile, Keanu Reeves returns as Johnny Silverhand, still rocking that “I hate the system” vibe but with a touch more existential dread. It’s like watching your cool uncle go through a mid-life crisis, but with more explosions.

Dogtown itself is a marvel. It’s like someone took all the worst parts of a dystopian future and decided to make it a tourist attraction. The local wildlife includes cyber-enhanced gangsters and vending machines that might just try to sell you a grenade. But hey, at least the street food is to die for—literally.

The gameplay is a rollercoaster of emotions. One moment you’re making life-or-death decisions, the next you’re wondering why your character’s pants have suddenly disappeared. It’s all part of the Cyberpunk experience, folks. Embrace the chaos.

In conclusion, Phantom Liberty is the perfect blend of high-stakes drama, cybernetic mayhem, and unintentional comedy. It’s like a soap opera set in a dystopian future, and honestly, we wouldn’t have it any other way. So, grab your cyberdeck, put on your best trench coat, and dive into the madness. Just watch out for those vending machines.

[h1]I went through all that life has to offer, just like you. I know how hard that s*** is.[/h1]

When [b]Like A Dragon: Infinite Wealth (LADIW)[/b] first trailer came out, I was really looking forward to coming back to the turn-based JRPG gameplay that the game was going for. I was really excited to what the game improved on with [b]Y7[/b] and what new features that the game had in store for it. With that said, this review will also be a bit hard for me to cover in certain aspects, as I don’t want to spoil anything on the game.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]A very interestingly crafted story with fun characters
[*]Fun turn-based gameplay
[*]Unique jobs that can give you a variety of moves
[*]Lots of side content to do in the game
[*]Fantastic soundtrack that is nice to listen to
[*]Beautiful graphics that make the areas feel alive
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The story loses some of its charm near the end
[*]New Game+ and other difficulties locked behind a DLC
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
[b]Ichiban Kasuga[/b] was working at an average job until he one day gets let go from his and cancled by a [b[Vtuber[/b] on in one day. This is due to a callout video made by a [b]Vtuber[/b] named [b]Hisoka Tatara[/b] and because of this [b]Kasuga[/b], with his two friends, [b]Nanba and Adachi[/b], decide to go to the [b]Seiryu clan[/b], to find answers. Along their way, they meet ex-yakuza members and meet [b]Jo Sawashiro[/b], who then tells [b]Kasuga[/b] to go to [b]Hawill[/b] and find his mother. Although there is a lot more going on then one may seem.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3333939084
The story for [b]LADIW[/b] is pretty good, I really loved the new characters and the returning ones were also nice. I honesty think even telling one of my favorite characters is spoiling the story too much, besides [b]Tomizawa[/b], who is a cab driver and was just a cool character. The story has that classic crime drama that the series is known for.

However, the story does lose some of its charm near the end of the game, as it falls off a tad bit although this is only a minor issue that I noticed. Everything else with the story is great but near the end, it kind of just goes away, although they do leave off with an interesting note for it’s next game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]LADIW’s[/b] gameplay mainly remains the same from the previous entry but there are some changes that I really loved that the game added. Besides [b]Kasuga[/b], everyone will now pick up objects to attack people if they are near them. So if you ever wanted to see [b]Nanba[/b] throw a bike at someone, well now you can. You can also use MP to cast special moves to deal more damage, buff/debuff someone, or heal. Overall, the gameplay is very fun and your characters can learn lots of moves to help them in combat.

During combat, you can also time the enemy's attacks so you can block them to do less damage. One of the newest things to combat for enemies is that they can be in a guard state, when they are in this, they will take reduced damage. To get them out of the guard state mainly, you have to use a grab attack, in which they will be taken out of that state. Your teammates also have a radius on their attacks, they can attack any enemy at any range but if they stay in the radius, they will do extra damage on that attack.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3333941765
Jobs are back as well and there are some unique ones that are with each party member. This time around, all the jobs in this game are very good and there isn’t one that is bad necessarily. However, there are some jobs that are ok for the most part but aren’t bad, it is up to personal preference but I never really came across a bad job in this game for any character. Especially [b]Joongi Han or Seonhee[/b] where their main jobs were just straight up broken.

If you want to switch jobs but keep a certain move, you can do it with a move transfer feature that the game has. Which is very useful to create the ultimate character with the best job with some of the best moves in another job. Although you can only do up to five moves in total completely. So make sure you have the moves that you want to use and keep note of them so you can make the most of them.

There is a ton of side content that the game has in it and some very interesting ones at that. The first one I would like to bring up is [b]Sujimon[/b], which is this game's version of [b]Pokemon[/b], where you battle [b]Sujimon[/b] trainers and challenge gym leaders. Then there is [b]Dondoko Island[/b], where you manage a hotel resort, it’s like [b]Animal Crossing[/b] to an extent. So as you can see, You have three games in one, [b]Like a Dragon Infinite Wealth, Pokemon, and Animal Crossing[/b]. There is a lot to the gameplay that I have not explained but I can’t fit it all into this review, I do talk a little more about this game in my video on it (will be out soon, ran into some problems}. I also rated all the [b]Yakuza[/b] games that I have played so if you are interested in that, keep an eye out for it.

Although despite having all of this great stuff in this game, [b]Infinite Wealth[/b] has one glaring issue with its gameplay or the game as a whole. New Game+, is locked behind a DLC and so is hard mode, in other words, you only have access to one difficulty for the game. The game isn’t that hard either but the fact that a basic game feature is locked behind a DLC just proves [b]Sega’s[/b] greed.

[h1]Graphics, Performance and Soundtrack[/h1]
The graphics for this game are beautiful and I loved how the world that you are in is detailed, each area felt real and it’s like I was in its world. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM, I had no issues while I was playing and I was able to play it just fine, on medium settings.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3333942218
The soundtrack for this game is just fantastic and it even rivals Y0’s soundtrack, my favorite songs in the game are [b]Camouflage, Barracuda, and Giftiger Füllhalter[/b]. These songs just sound so damn nice to listen to and I highly recommend you check them out when given the chance.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
[b]Infinite Wealth[/b] is one of the best games that I have played this year and I am glad I was able to experience it in all its glory. I recommend this game to all [b]Yakuza[/b] fans, especially for those who enjoyed [b]Y7[/b]. You will have a great time with this game and the side content will make sure you are hooked and are playing the game for hours on end.

Filler. Padding. Nonsense.
Three words that fit this game perfectly. There is nothing more infuriating then trying to get on with a game's story just to be thrown into a forced animal crossing bootleg tutorial. The game's story (when it isn't extremely predictable or being hindered by endless filler) is pretty good and I want to see more of it, so it's a shame that you have to trudge through sneaking through crowded streets of enemies for an hour to get to it. It got to the point where I just had to go on WeMod and turn on stealth mode. This game could have been great, but since the seventh entry they've really dropped the ball with the franchise.
Also Ichiban is not a good character. Having a character obnoxiously looking for the good in horrid people doesn't make him a good guy, it makes him stupid, and no matter how hard you try to push this "him and Kiryu are so alike" point it will never make it true.

( full review with screenshots: https://www.gaming-parrot.com/post/infinite-wealth-review-infinite-content )

At a whopping 127 hours by Steam playtime, Infinite Wealth is now the longest game I've ever played by a huge margin. It took me nearly 40 hours longer than its predecessor, and over 30 hours longer than it took to earn a platinum trophy in Persona 5 Royal. Whatever else you want to say about this game, you can't say that you're not getting your money's worth. The bigger question is whether this incredible level of time investment is worth it. Although this is in many ways a great game, it's harder than I'd like to say that it was 127 hours well spent. 

Let's start with the good news. The main story is well done, and you could probably get through it in a relatively normal amount of time for a JRPG if you're focused on it. It has some fun fights and a lot of callbacks that I'm sure are exciting and rewarding content if you've played Yakuza 0-6. The new characters are deeply integrated into the plot and have satisfying arcs. Honolulu is a fun city to explore and feels as different from Ijincho as you'd expect.

A lot of the other things that were good in the last game remain fun. The battle system is still great, and made more so by new jobs. The music is great. There are some entertaining side quests, the minigames are gloriously stupid, and so on. You'd expect at least a few things that are horribly underdeveloped in a game this long, but everything is basically fine at a minimum. 

The bad news is that while nothing truly feels incomplete, many parts of the game would have benefited from more refinement. Although the minigames are fun, there are only a handful of new ones and there's nothing as crazy as kart racing or running a public company from the last game. Most of them, like the parodies of Crazy Taxi and Pokemon Snap are solid experiences that run out of new content after 20 minutes and don't have worthwhile rewards. The highlights are supposed to be Donodoko Island and Sujimon battling, which parody Animal Crossing and Pokemon respectively, but neither of them have the depth to reach their full potential. Dondoko island boils down to spamming buildings all over your island until you get the next cutscene, and Sujimon battling is almost entirely determined by who has the best rarity Sujimon at the highest level. Since each Sujimon only has one move and all moves do pretty much the same thing with different damage totals, there's little reason to anything other than mash A and occasionally swap for type matchups. You need to complete Dondoko Island and the Sujimon league if you want to complete all the quests, but they're each long enough that you could have finished an entirely different game instead. That was one thing in the last game when the minigames were as fun as many other full games, but in this case it really didn't feel worth the time. 

Sadly, the minigames aren't the only place where you get the feeling that the devs didn't get all the time they needed. The story rushes to make sure every major character returns, but several of them clearly have no reason to be back and barely play any role other than being present. The final battles at the end of the game are well made and difficult, but the evil monologues you're treated to reveal that the villains never really had any kind of coherent plan, which makes you wonder what the point of it all was and whether there was supposed to be more content that would have tied everything together better. It's all capped off by one of the main party characters not even being present for the epilogue and instead just getting a single sentence to explain what happened. It's not quite "and then everybody died, the end", but it's hard to imagine an explanation other than not having time to make another epilogue cutscene. 

At the end of the day, Infinite Wealth is a great game that just tries to do too much. RGG wanted to have a sendoff for Kiryu while also telling a new story on the scale of the last game, and they really should have picked one or the other. Although they do a better job of integrating those two very disparate goals than you might expect, trying to cram all of that into a game with anything resembling a normal runtime just means that nothing gets the time it deserved. It's still a good game, but I can't help but wonder if it would have been better as two separate games that each had a single goal. If nothing else, that would have prevented the need to break the cast up into two small parties and given you more flexibility to build your battle team. 

--------
For more reviews, see [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43219041]my curator page[/url]

This game is incredible. I know some fans of the Yakuza series have criticized parts of this game's story, and understandably so, but this game more than makes up for it. Hawaii as a setting for Ichiban and his pals works so well it seems like they've always been there. Every single part of the map is blooming with beautiful sights to see, and fun things to do. From the main story, to the side quests, to the many alternate game modes, this game never stops entertaining you. The story for this game is it's most divisive part, and for me it was my favorite part. I was an orphan myself, and the fact that a huge portion of Ichiban's story in this game was getting to see his birth-mother again was a beautiful thing that every adopted child wishes they could do. The scenes with Ichiban reminiscing on his family and what could have been felt like things that have gone through my head a hundred times. Kiryu's story was also somber. With our favorite dragon now having cancer, he can't fight like he used to. He learns to rely on his friends, which is a lesson everybody needs to learn eventually. The finale for both of these incredible characters fit perfectly within their themes, and it ends in an extremely satisfying way. The new characters are also fantastic. Chitose, Tomizawa, and Yamai are all realistic characters with interesting backstories and they fit right in with all of our favorites. The combat here is also a massive step-up from Yakuza 7. We now have movement options within the fights, which make planning and executing your moves that much more strategic. Add in an insane number of jobs, and you have a combat system that's fun all the way through. This game has so much to offer to so many different types of people, and that's why the Yakuza franchise is so incredible. Please play this game. You won't regret it.

I wish I could give this game a sideways. The general whole is enjoyable. The difficulty is mostly enjoyable. I would only recommend it to diehard souls-like fans.
