Describing my experience with Lies of P as simply another 'souls-like ARPG' would be entirely reductive to the amount of passion & attention-to-detail presented by the teams at Neowiz and Round8 Studio. Lies of P sees you lead as Gepetto's puppet in a twisted, gloomy take on the folktale of Pinocchio. Waking up in an eerie train station, you soon make your way outside to the city of Krat, where a sudden trigger in the puppets causes a haunting massacre that sets the tone for the rest of the game.

     On that note, atmosphere is the name. Hotel Krat is your central hub, and it quickly evolved from being a brief trip to level up my weapons into a safe retreat where I could listen to a vibrant soundtrack in the background as I spoke with the many charismatic faces that made up this iconic location. It's not just the hub area - everything from oil-lined streets to infested cathedrals, the immense amount of detail present within the level design itself across most of the chapters is incredibly impressive. Whether it was my first playthrough or my sixth, I could not help but immerse myself in all of the intricately placed bodies & texts around the city that truly cements this game as an all-time example of how to do proper environmental storytelling within linear experiences. Neowiz and Round8 really wear the inspiration on their sleeves with the worldbuilding here and it's very well executed. (Note: it runs flawlessly for me on an upper-end rig, but even on my steam deck it is the best performing game I own. It's also very nicely balanced and well-paced. I would say I preferred the difficulty around launch, as it really heightened my enjoyment of this game in a unique way because of how challenging it was. But it's still a decent challenge and NG+ definitely brought that difficulty back.) 

     Combat is really where Lies of P hits all of its strides for me. As a fan of FromSoftware's 'soulsborne' entries for the better part of a decade, I believe Lies of P implements so many positive spins on their formula that I would recommend this over the traditional souls games to any player, regardless of experience (well... maybe play Sekiro.) For example, one of my favorite mechanics is pulse recharge, which allows you to gain one more charge to your healing consumable if you are at zero. This feature would change the entire dynamic of so many of my fights in an instant. Maybe I'm playing defensively, I've got two more heals and 60% of the boss's health left; in scenarios like this, every single time I reached zero heals, my brain would switch to aggression immediately in the hopes of regaining a charge and feel more 'comfortable.' I cannot speak to everyone's experience, but this mechanic made me a better player over time as I was PUSHED into being more active in my gameplay and subsequently rewarded with the most satisfying sound effect I've heard since the Halo CE shield recharge as a single pulse cell materializes right back into your upper belt. 

     Another great feature to the combat sandbox is the ability to assemble weapons. This is the single-most innovative design choice that Lies of P offers. Every weapon comes in two distinct parts, the blade tip and the handle. Each part has their respective stats; however, you can alter the handle to scale off of different stats than the ones it drops with. This opens up a lot of customization and encourages player experimentation, because at no extra-cost, your entire moveset and ability options can change in a matter of seconds. I myself am a Guts sword girl through and through, but even I felt compelled to experiment and eventually beat the game with my own ridiculous combinations. (Note: For me, this self-expression was VERY important in my enjoyment of the game, and I think it's a great innovation to the souls combat formula to allow your players to test out ANY weapon handle's moveset with... every other weapon's blade. Admittedly boss weapons are restricted from being customized and the scaling of both parts' stab/slash stat means that your options for good damage are inherently limited, but it offers so much freedom regardless that I would not mind seeing it return in the sequel.) 

     Story is the point I want to end this off on. For as long as I have cherished Bloodborne's lore, the original trilogy's lore, etc. I have never actually felt connected to the events of the stories presented in souls-like games. There's always been a strange disconnect for me being able to enjoy the challenge of the gameplay rather than caring about the story. I can say Lies of P genuinely moved me in a way no other games in this subgenre have. I believe the most obvious explanation for this is the greater emphasis on dialogue and player onboarding that Lies of P engages in. There is a real sense here with the amount of dialogue you'll receive from a character off-screen during gameplay or in the middle of a boss fight that Neowiz really wanted to make players feel INVOLVED in the big character moments as they are happening, rather than reading about them from a lore description (which is also a method of storytelling present with a lot to read up on that is engaging.) To be clear, I have no issue with this, but I really prefer the focus on character engaging with me, the truths/lies you decide to tell them, and the almost-immediate consequences those decisions can have as they relay their reactions back to you. You can ignore or fight multiple bosses by making a simple decision. I like that. The narrative throughline that is happening above all of the character stories is decently executed, but the character quests is really where Lies of P shines (shoutout to Arlecchino.) Everyone is voice acted phenomenally, and this could not be a Lies of P review without making mention of how pivotal this game's original soundtrack is to the overall experience. The music feels tied to the characters' stories, as many records you can play back at Hotel Krat are received from quest completions. This makes even something as seemingly trivial as playing a record on a record player feel rewarding in itself, as you learn more about an NPC's journey through this world or simply enjoy a great tune in the background. 

     This has become my comfort game, and affectionately so. That doesn't mean it is devoid of things I disliked, as the final area of the game, Arche Abbey, has got to be the single-most tedious level I have played in recent memory. Running through this moody grey wasteland to a grey tower with grey floors and repeated enemies from throughout the entire game got tiring incredibly fast, and it's a shame that the area with this game's pinnacle challenges is also so uninspired in its design. Additionally, I do not think the armor system, dubbed "Defense parts," is particularly exciting. I think this could be fleshed out a little more, but finding more parts throughout the game is almost never exciting because they are always going to be better than your previous find, and they do not change any part of your puppet's appearance. I do like the cosmetics available here, but I definitely prefer the more free-form style of armor expression in other souls-likes. The legion arm system is probably the most disappointing aspect for me, delivering options to customize your limb similar to the prosthetic tools in Sekiro. I do not like the implementation in this game because it feels stiff to me. This is not something I have the knowledge to explain away, but it feels very restricted and with the low amount of legion I always have, it just left a lot to be desired for me because I mainly relied on parrying and counterattacking. 

     Despite my negatives, I adore this game. At the time of writing I have unlocked everything pre-DLC and waiting in anticipation for it as well as the recently announced sequel. If you've ever got a weekend to knockout a surprisingly compelling souls-like, this is absolutely the one for you.

This game is fantastic. Hands down the best souls-like not made my Fromsoft.

Combat is fast-paced and has a bit of a learning curve, but is extremely satisfying once it clicks. Learning when to parry vs block, attack with a weapon vs throwbacks vs weapon art was fun and engaging. 

It also looks great and runs smoothly. Even on the Steam Deck with decent graphic settings, I was easily keeping 60 FPS.

Some people have criticized it for not being as open world as a game like Elden Ring, but I see that as a positive aspect of Lies of P. Being able to have a more linear path made the gameplay tight and paced well. It also never felt like it overstayed it's welcome, like I wind up feeling about many open world games.

This is the only game I've ever been motivated to 100% and can't wait for the DLC and sequel.

2 hours in, performance is fine. 60 - 90 FPS on high, 1440p on a 3060TI, 11600k with 32 gig of RAM. On the latest video drivers from nvidia, on patch 2 of the game, and let the shaders compile before playing (which didn't take long).

Will update if something major changes, but if you are holding out because of sporadic reports of performance issues at 1440p on an 8 gig card, they are either sorted out (patch 2) or were due to other factors (out-of-date drivers, etc). Or, I guess, I haven't played long enough to run into them.

I played it on PS5 and I must admit with a over-mid specced PC this port is the better one with its potential for framerate and graphics. The game itself is very good, you get a great action flick for the money you pay - with great character development, plot twists, gameplay additions and likely a better experience than the previous instalment offered. I'm recommending and warning you against buying this game at the same time.

You have the problems - the game's approach to puzzles is literally insulting to your intelligence. Every time you encounter a puzzle, the companion you're with tells you how to solve it before you even have a chance to take a look around. "Hey, maybe that thing above you is gonna open a pathway" and that's literally every puzzle in the game. This should be an accessibility option, you should be able to shut your companions up when you're trying to solve the already trivial puzzles. Sure the combat is still nice, story is nice, but this? Its insulting. Not a single puzzle goes without your companion telling you exactly how to solve it. "Woow, what if we freeze this?" and the moment you try anything, they will say something like "oh no maybe lets try something else" or "oh yes we did it" to indicate the correct solution which they already gave to you to begin with.

LOOK HERE    ---->    The PSN drama isn't as bad here as it was with helldivers, since in helldivers you could buy and play the game for like 3 months before they made it impossible to play for some regions. Here on the other hand you had warnings of the PSN requirement from the very start. Is it okay to have mandatory PSN requirements for a PC version of a single player game? 
Definitely a garbage decision which is clearly one of the biggest flaws of the newer games to come out. Some regions will require you to link a phone number to check your age, I think it is the case for the UK. The other ones will ask for your postal code and real name - it's all going to a third party website which is KNOWN for losing your data to frequent data leaks and hacks. Obviously PSN doesn't care whether you own or even intend to own a PS5 for this, you still need the account because they want to collect more data, it's as simple as this.

Having said that, I think the game itself is great, the unlocked framerate makes it even smoother to play to be honest. Then on the other hand, if you're not okay with this invasion on your personal data security, maybe rethink purchasing it. Same applies to some specific regions of the world which require even more data than other regions. I really suggest you look it up before you buy the game.

TLDR: PSN bad, game doesn't respect your intelligence with insane amounts of handholding but good story and good gameplay overall. Not goty but buy this if you can overlook the PSN drama.

Definitely really tried to like this game. The art and music is amazing, but the game is EXTREMELY grindy. 

The game definitely feels like it doesn't respect your time with a fairly large map that takes awhile to move around in. Making things such as a minecart network feels like a hassle, since mine carts  / boats aren't equipped to your character, but placed on the rail network, so if you die, you'll have to walk all the way back to get your vehicle.  Fast travel points are few and far between, and the only way (As far as I know) to create an additional fast travel point is extremely resource intensive and has a TEN minute cooldown.

You'll also need a large amount of materials for a lot of stuff in the game, which the game seems to flirt with automating the process a bit by having automated drills to get these resources for you.  The way you can automate things is extremely basic however, and will require you to just randomly explore until you find an appropriate node you can place your drills at. 

The gearing for combat in this game also feels pretty basic, and doesn't have as much synergies as I'd like. For example, I equipped an armour set that increases crit chance upon poisoning an enemy. However I found that this trait doesn't proc when using a range weapon that poisons enemies, when using a character skill that inflicts poison whenever you deal damage, or when using a pet that poisons enemies. It seems to only proc when using a poison melee weapon - which wasn't mentioned in the description of the armour set. 

The breaking point for me in this game was [spoiler] A large underwater sea section, which you basically need a boat for traveling around at. There's a water boss in this section without a fast travel point near it. Dying to it not only means having to make the long trek back, but you'll either need to remake your really expensive boat or make a long land bridge back to your stuff[/spoiler]

Ultimately, I was looking for something to scratch my survival crafting itch, but there's not enough here to justify the massive grind.

I have never been into 2d games, I have never been into civ building, I have never been into indie games. 

And I love this! Time flies when you are playing this.

I did a full play through with a friend in a single seed to 100% the game in a little over 120 hours.  The progression of this game is fantastic and the crafting system is easy to use/follow.  Go-karts, Boating, PvE, PVP, boss battles... I was never bored playing this game as there is always something to do.  The customization you are allowed to make in game is endless (painting, flooring, walls, farming, automation, mob spawning, etc.).  Essentially you need to defeat certain bosses to gather parts to power the core, which will unlock more of the available map.  There are also optional bosses, ALL of which have fun mechanics and I recommend trying all boss fights.  The appearance of the game to me was appealing, giving almost a retro feel to the game.  This game felt like it took great aspects from other games I've played and put it into one. 
 Very fun game, definitely recommend it.  

Things I've learned/tips:
1.)  Using the Map - to place the Icons, select the desired icon and click the middle mouse button on the map to add; click on same spot to remove.  Mark boss fighting/summoning locations to find easier later on.
2.)  If you want to customize flooring that doesn't allow it to be painted; put a "glass floor" on top of it, then paint it.  May find a color you like w/ that pattern.
3.)  Create Scanners to find bosses, sooo much more convenient than blindly running around the map.
4.)  Save the figurines you collect.  There's a way to "power" them to have them spawn that type of mob; they do not drop loot, though still grant exp for your skill ups.
5.)  You have 3 different gear sets, recommend binding those sets to hotkeys.  Some fights may be much easier if/when you switch armor sets/tactics during the fight.

Hope the above helps, enjoy!

The game has been super fun. Started with hard mode and it provided enough of a challenge to keep the game interesting. The game provides enough variety of activities to keep you exploring without tiring out from any one activity. When you get tired of fishing, for example, you move on to something else for a while. 

I'm not a min/max kind of player, so I do my own builds with whatever I find via natural play through and was able to find some of the legendary weapons in good time. Ranged weapons are very good in this game, especially physical ranged like the daggers. Overall, Armor sets favor physical melee and ranged builds. There are some for casters or summoners as well, but they aren't very strong end game and fall off fast. Mainly because there are only two books to summon creatures. At some point  the mana cost gets to be too high and the bats are too dumb for combat situations to really focus on summons and I found myself using daggers or other weapons like the fireball staff to compensate. I really really tried making a summoner build work on its own, but I couldn't get through some of the content even though I was geared fairly well. Switched to physical range and beat everything no problem. At the time of me writing this, I have only the remaining two titans left, which I'm about to tackle next. 

Good game and definitely worth playing. Can't wait to see what else they'll add. Hoping that summoners get some more love

40 hrs so far and for the most part, Ive really had a good time. I do feel like the game suffers from an identity crisis. Does it want to be an open world survival like Minecraft, something casual like Stardew Valley, or more of a Boss a Rush type of game?

The postive thing ia that you get a little bit of all 3, but the negative is that you have to deal with game mechanics that intentionally slow you down.

Example, Trying to farm Wool, but you can only do it every 10 real time minutes. Bosses that have a cooldown before they respawn. Or farming for the 3 upgrade materials, Emearld,Ruby, and Sapphire which take forever without a Mob spawner. 

If you can look past the obnoxious grind for materials, I think youll enjoy your stay here. Alot of these materials arent necessary until later in the game depending on how fast you push into the next zone.


Boss are cool. Lots of sets and diversities. The upgrade station allows all early gear to stay relevant if one choose to upgrade them. 

Looking forward to future updates. Hoping they remove uncessary bottlenecking or change them in a way that is less annoying. 

Example, Cattle should give the materials right away, Then go on a cooldown. Instead of feeding them, waiting 10 mintues then getting the item.

I got some hours into the game. It's a hard game to get bored of.  Just not the factions are different from each other, so are the lords within those factions. There are enough DLC's, free content, and updates to keep the gave fresh. 

The journey of the game was different from most franchises since in some respects, each Warhammer can be considered one big DLC. I say this as a positive, because it makes the world massive and gives a great of variety of different play throughs. 

The meat of the game isn't the campaign(s), it's "Immortal Empires" the game mode that brings all games together. However I do hope one day they do make a final campaign or even a game mode where it's the forces of "good" vs "Evil" working together.

It's total war, in the WH universe. Cool units, neat maps, so many items and abilities for lords and heros.

This installment of Total War has been the best one by far, in my opinion, having some of the most interesting combat, Lords, Heroes and Unit rosters per Faction. Albeit, they had some issues with some of the DLC they still made a great game.

Over the years, between the 3 games I have 5150 hrs, that's approximately 215 days of play. I think thats a resounding YES! And/or a caution that you can lose yourself in this fantasy world. 

The "price gauging" is an industry thing, not specific to this game but it did lead to a massive review bomb here. The dev's have responded admirably to that and have made noticeably positive changes to their roadmap. The current situation stands "Here's some DLC. If you're interested in some or all, pay for want you want." Considering the time and effort that goes into this, + the recent dev dives for the future, I dont think the "mixed reviews" mean anything any more. 

The Workshop enabled mod scene adds almost infinite replayability to this game.

100% YES, What are you waiting for?

23 dlcs (a # that will only go up in the coming months) AND you have to own the previous installations to access their respective base factions. You'd have to be insane or rich to not buy anything here on sale. 

I'm going to recommend the game because I consider it worthwhile for what I paid for. It's a nice battle simulator even if you're not familiar with Warhammer. However, you must do your homework to see if this is the game for you.

Tiny Glade: A Soothing Escape into Creative Tranquility.


A Personal Journey into Peaceful Creativity:

From the moment I launched Tiny Glade, I felt as though I'd stepped into a serene oasis far removed from the hustle and bustle of daily life. Developed by the indie studio Pounce Light, this game isn't just about building structures—it's about building moments of peace and allowing your imagination to wander freely.


Visual Poetry in Motion:

The game's visuals are nothing short of enchanting. The hand-crafted art style feels warm and inviting, like flipping through the pages of a beautifully illustrated storybook. Each element, from the gently swaying trees to the softly glowing windows of a cottage, is rendered with such care that it’s impossible not to feel a sense of wonder. I often found myself pausing just to watch the way the sunlight filtered through the leaves or how the shadows danced across the rolling hills.


Embracing the Freedom to Create:

What sets Tiny Glade apart is its emphasis on unstructured creativity. There are no timers ticking down or resources to hoard—just an open canvas waiting for your touch. The grid-free building system felt incredibly liberating. I could effortlessly draw a winding stone wall that morphed seamlessly into a quaint archway or let a cobblestone path meander through a meadow without constraints.

At one point, I started constructing a small village nestled at the edge of a forest. As I added little details—a lantern here, a flowerbed there—the place began to feel alive. It was as if the game was encouraging me to tell my own story without uttering a single word.


An Auditory Hug:

The sound design is like a gentle hug for your ears. The soft rustle of leaves, distant bird songs, and the occasional whisper of the wind combined to create a soundscape that was both relaxing and rejuvenating. The music is subtle, never overpowering the experience, but always enhancing the mood.

Reflections on User Experience:

Navigating through Tiny Glade is a breeze. The intuitive controls allowed me to focus on creating rather than fumbling with mechanics. There was a moment when I accidentally erased a section of my build, and instead of feeling frustrated, I found that the game's forgiving nature turned it into an opportunity to try something new. It's rare to find a game that so seamlessly blends user-friendliness with depth.


The Joy of Unwinding:

In a world where games often demand so much from us—be it quick reflexes, strategic thinking, or constant vigilance—Tiny Glade is a welcome reprieve. It's a space where you can slow down, take a deep breath, and let your mind wander.


Final Thoughts:

Tiny Glade isn't just a game; it's an experience—a gentle reminder of the joy found in simplicity and creativity. It rekindles that childlike wonder we often lose along the way. Whether you're an avid gamer looking for something different or someone who simply wants a peaceful escape, Tiny Glade offers a sanctuary worth visiting.

[b]Intro:[/b]
[i]I am a seasoned gamer, I played from A to Z, hundreds and even more hundreds of games since the '90, I know my games and am proud of it. I saw this game, a few days ago, thought it looked nice, relaxing; I saw it had a demo and that its full release wasn't far away. I got immediately hooked, Elden Ring style, but without the frustration and concentration factor, replaced with utter calmness, peace of mind.[/i]

[b]Review(?):[/b]
The game itself is as easy as formidable, it delivers in what it wants you to do and what you actually want to do.
I'm no architect, but I managed to create little scenarios that made me chuckle as I was astonished by how beautiful and cute everything looked; every time I am done and happy with the results of that session, I take screenshots.
You could include "Background Creator" in the game's tags, because they are so gorgeous and "soft" that it calms you just by looking at a picture of something you created, out of literally nothing.

-Having the possibility to play a demo is a major up: every game should give you this opportunity before buying.

-The price is.. great, I was afraid to find 30-40-50 euros at its release, but they stayed true to what the game is; it's easy to find games that cost double and triple of this one and aren't this memorable nowadays, so thank you for that.

-No crash has ever happened, not in the full release nor the demo. I locked it at 60fps, render scale at 1.1 having my pc's performance set quite low so to not make it work, practically at all. Increasing the render scale increases the impact on your pc by a lot, can't say why as I have quite good specs. Upping the render scale to "just" 2.0 squashes my fps to around 20, but I'm using my pc in, almost, sleep mode. If you have problems with performance, lower the render scale by 0.1 until you're happy, it will still look good.

-I've read some reviews that say how this game is lacking in content, that they played a couple dozen minutes and "finished it", to that I can just say that they aren't made for this kind of games and that would be ok if they would say so. Not recommending a game that isn't in your alley, and not specifying it, is in my opinion, wrong. You could play hundreds of hours and not get tired (please not consecutively); the content is in your head. I just put a window on corner of a tower-like square building, then I put a second, and a third, at the end I had a section of the tower converted into a 360° window, it all worked so good and naturally that I stopped and thought what a great job the devs made, because they did.

-Sometimes it's "hard" to start without nothing, but if you continue you'll be amazed by the results; the glades start with something already pre-built, to give you an idea and the daily "challenge" is great for a quick session where you continue something, I presume, they created for the occasion.

[b]Verdict:[/b]
A cute and relaxing building/city builder that gives you the reins to your imagination (in this context of course).
Enough content for as long as your imagination is fresh and trained, or you're willing to let go for a while and just click away; there's a start, but no end.
I am sure they'll add even more nice content, decorations, not for us to place individually, but seamlessly attack to what is around it (tables and chair on a flat roof for example), maybe more wall designs; I'm very confident they'll continue to work on it, and deliver.

It's a [b]9/10[/b] for me, it is just that beautiful and meets its promises like no other game lately.

If you’ve ever wondered what it would be like to survive in a world overrun by zombies, Project Zomboid is the game for you. With a heavy focus on realism and player choice, this survival sandbox offers a deeply immersive experience that few other games can match. Whether you’re managing your character’s health, building your dream base, or evading hordes of undead, Project Zomboid keeps you on your toes at every moment. Having spent over 730 hours in the game, I can confidently say that it delivers one of the best survival experiences available today.

1. Realism Done Right
Despite the fictional backdrop of a zombie apocalypse, Project Zomboid nails realism in almost every aspect of gameplay. The most valuable tip for any new player is simply: "What would you do in this situation?" The game's health system is intricate, with injuries, illnesses, and mental states all playing a role. Clothes protect you from zombie bites, degrade over time, and help regulate body temperature, which is vital. Mechanics like repairing vehicles, dealing with character traits and professions, and managing inventory weight make everything feel real. I especially love how character emotions and moods affect gameplay – it’s small touches like these that elevate Project Zomboid to another level of immersion.

2. An Open World That Never Ends
The current game world is massive, and despite having played over 730 hours, I still didn't explore all the areas. I admire the sheer size of the map, and with upcoming updates promising to expand it further and even include randomly generated maps in the distant future. Project Zomboid also offers infinite gameplay and replayability. It’s one of those survival games you can play over and over without ever getting tired.

3. Sandbox Customization Options
One of my favorite aspects is the ability to tailor the world to your liking. From the number and behavior of zombies to loot distribution, characters (players), and more, Project Zomboid lets you tweak almost anything. It gives you the power to create a world that fits your personal playstyle or challenge yourself with tougher scenarios.

4. Character Creation and Professions
This is hands-down one of my favorite features in the game. Choosing different professions and character traits, both positive and negative, significantly changes how the game plays. I also appreciate the subtle bonuses and drawbacks that aren’t immediately obvious – it adds an extra layer of depth. The balance in this system is present, too, so don’t expect to create an overpowered character unless you tweak the sandbox settings to do so!

5. Community Mods
While Project Zomboid doesn’t need mods to be great, the fact that they’re available is a huge bonus. The modding community has added incredible content, from enhanced realism to new vehicles, traits, weapons, and crafting options. There’s too much to describe in one review! That said, I recommend playing without mods at first to truly grasp the game’s mechanics, but later on, mods can make the experience even better.

6. Skill Levels and Physical Attributes
Project Zomboid features an extensive skill system that allows players to improve their characters through practice and experience. Skills are divided into categories like combat, crafting, survival, and agility, each having a noticeable impact on gameplay. Combat skills such as aiming and reloading become crucial for firearm users, while melee skills like blunt and blade proficiency determine how effective you are with weapons like baseball bats or axes. Crafting skills, including carpentry, metalworking, and tailoring, let you fortify your base, repair clothes, or even create tools from scratch.
Survival skills like foraging and fishing allow you to live off the land when resources run dry, and farming lets you grow your own food, providing a sustainable source of nutrition. Agility skills, such as sneaking and lightfooted, are essential for staying hidden from zombies, while sprinting helps you escape when the situation gets dire.
Physical attributes like strength and fitness are equally important, as they directly affect how much weight you can carry, how fast you tire, and how effective you are in combat. Improving your strength means you can carry heavier loads and hit harder with melee attacks, while better fitness ensures you can run longer distances and recover faster from exhaustion. Each skill progresses the more you use it, making every action in the game feel meaningful and rewarding.

7. Intriguing (But Optional) Lore
While the storyline isn’t central to the player’s experience yet, it does exist, and it’s fascinating. I only started diving into the game’s lore after playing for about 500 hours, and once I did, I was hooked. I went so far as to read up on the game’s backstory online (beware of spoilers!) Exploring the lore adds a new dimension to the game. I highly recommend getting to know the lore yourself!

8. A Sandbox Experience
Want to build? Build. Want to destroy? Go ahead. In Project Zomboid, your creativity (and characters human possibilities) are your only limits. The only challenge is gathering materials, which makes sense given the post-apocalyptic setting. But with enough time and motivation, you can accomplish incredible things. This open-ended approach is perfect for players who enjoy creating and building their own worlds.

9. Active Developer Support
The game is still in early access, and while it may not be updated on a daily basis, the developers deliver large, meaningful updates. They listen to player feedback, fix bugs, and continue to improve the game without ignoring the community, which is something I greatly respect.

10. Hidden Depths
Just when you think you’ve learned everything there is to know about Project Zomboid, it surprises you. The game is full of hidden mechanics and features that add to the depth of the experience. I’ve had several moments where I thought I had mastered the game, only to discover a new layer of complexity. It’s a game that keeps on giving.

11. Fair Price
Finally, let’s talk about the price. For what Project Zomboid offers, the price is perfect. But if you’re looking to save a bit of money, it’s always worth waiting for a sale. Either way, you’re getting your money’s worth for this gem of a game.

Project Zomboid is a truly exceptional survival game that combines deep realism with sandbox freedom. Whether you're fighting off zombies, building your own fortress, or scavenging for supplies, every moment feels impactful. With continuous updates, an active modding community, and endless replayability, it’s a game that will keep you coming back for more. I can’t recommend it highly enough to fans of survival games or anyone looking for a challenging, immersive experience.

Definitely really tried to like this game. The art and music is amazing, but the game is EXTREMELY grindy. 

The game definitely feels like it doesn't respect your time with a fairly large map that takes awhile to move around in. Making things such as a minecart network feels like a hassle, since mine carts  / boats aren't equipped to your character, but placed on the rail network, so if you die, you'll have to walk all the way back to get your vehicle.  Fast travel points are few and far between, and the only way (As far as I know) to create an additional fast travel point is extremely resource intensive and has a TEN minute cooldown.

You'll also need a large amount of materials for a lot of stuff in the game, which the game seems to flirt with automating the process a bit by having automated drills to get these resources for you.  The way you can automate things is extremely basic however, and will require you to just randomly explore until you find an appropriate node you can place your drills at. 

The gearing for combat in this game also feels pretty basic, and doesn't have as much synergies as I'd like. For example, I equipped an armour set that increases crit chance upon poisoning an enemy. However I found that this trait doesn't proc when using a range weapon that poisons enemies, when using a character skill that inflicts poison whenever you deal damage, or when using a pet that poisons enemies. It seems to only proc when using a poison melee weapon - which wasn't mentioned in the description of the armour set. 

The breaking point for me in this game was [spoiler] A large underwater sea section, which you basically need a boat for traveling around at. There's a water boss in this section without a fast travel point near it. Dying to it not only means having to make the long trek back, but you'll either need to remake your really expensive boat or make a long land bridge back to your stuff[/spoiler]

Ultimately, I was looking for something to scratch my survival crafting itch, but there's not enough here to justify the massive grind.

I have never been into 2d games, I have never been into civ building, I have never been into indie games. 

And I love this! Time flies when you are playing this.

I did a full play through with a friend in a single seed to 100% the game in a little over 120 hours.  The progression of this game is fantastic and the crafting system is easy to use/follow.  Go-karts, Boating, PvE, PVP, boss battles... I was never bored playing this game as there is always something to do.  The customization you are allowed to make in game is endless (painting, flooring, walls, farming, automation, mob spawning, etc.).  Essentially you need to defeat certain bosses to gather parts to power the core, which will unlock more of the available map.  There are also optional bosses, ALL of which have fun mechanics and I recommend trying all boss fights.  The appearance of the game to me was appealing, giving almost a retro feel to the game.  This game felt like it took great aspects from other games I've played and put it into one. 
 Very fun game, definitely recommend it.  

Things I've learned/tips:
1.)  Using the Map - to place the Icons, select the desired icon and click the middle mouse button on the map to add; click on same spot to remove.  Mark boss fighting/summoning locations to find easier later on.
2.)  If you want to customize flooring that doesn't allow it to be painted; put a "glass floor" on top of it, then paint it.  May find a color you like w/ that pattern.
3.)  Create Scanners to find bosses, sooo much more convenient than blindly running around the map.
4.)  Save the figurines you collect.  There's a way to "power" them to have them spawn that type of mob; they do not drop loot, though still grant exp for your skill ups.
5.)  You have 3 different gear sets, recommend binding those sets to hotkeys.  Some fights may be much easier if/when you switch armor sets/tactics during the fight.

Hope the above helps, enjoy!

The game has been super fun. Started with hard mode and it provided enough of a challenge to keep the game interesting. The game provides enough variety of activities to keep you exploring without tiring out from any one activity. When you get tired of fishing, for example, you move on to something else for a while. 

I'm not a min/max kind of player, so I do my own builds with whatever I find via natural play through and was able to find some of the legendary weapons in good time. Ranged weapons are very good in this game, especially physical ranged like the daggers. Overall, Armor sets favor physical melee and ranged builds. There are some for casters or summoners as well, but they aren't very strong end game and fall off fast. Mainly because there are only two books to summon creatures. At some point  the mana cost gets to be too high and the bats are too dumb for combat situations to really focus on summons and I found myself using daggers or other weapons like the fireball staff to compensate. I really really tried making a summoner build work on its own, but I couldn't get through some of the content even though I was geared fairly well. Switched to physical range and beat everything no problem. At the time of me writing this, I have only the remaining two titans left, which I'm about to tackle next. 

Good game and definitely worth playing. Can't wait to see what else they'll add. Hoping that summoners get some more love

40 hrs so far and for the most part, Ive really had a good time. I do feel like the game suffers from an identity crisis. Does it want to be an open world survival like Minecraft, something casual like Stardew Valley, or more of a Boss a Rush type of game?

The postive thing ia that you get a little bit of all 3, but the negative is that you have to deal with game mechanics that intentionally slow you down.

Example, Trying to farm Wool, but you can only do it every 10 real time minutes. Bosses that have a cooldown before they respawn. Or farming for the 3 upgrade materials, Emearld,Ruby, and Sapphire which take forever without a Mob spawner. 

If you can look past the obnoxious grind for materials, I think youll enjoy your stay here. Alot of these materials arent necessary until later in the game depending on how fast you push into the next zone.


Boss are cool. Lots of sets and diversities. The upgrade station allows all early gear to stay relevant if one choose to upgrade them. 

Looking forward to future updates. Hoping they remove uncessary bottlenecking or change them in a way that is less annoying. 

Example, Cattle should give the materials right away, Then go on a cooldown. Instead of feeding them, waiting 10 mintues then getting the item.

I went in expecting something similar to Katana Zero, but it's so much more than that. Saying Sanabi is a Katana Zero clone would be a huge disservice to this game. To me, both are exceptional gems.

But before I continue to sing my praises to this game, what exactly is Sanabi?

Well, in this action platformer game, you play as a retired veteran with a simple mission, which is to hunt an entity called "Sanabi". To do this, you will use your chain hook prosthetic arm to get around a city called Mago. This weapon can also be used to hook yourself to the enemies, destroying them in the process.

This grappling hook mechanism means that you will spend most of your time in the air, going from one platform to another, from one enemy to another, from one boss to another. And when done right, it feels oh so good, especially because of the tight movement. Makes you feel unstoppable, and it gets the adrenaline pumping!

I said "when done right", because at first, I struggled getting used to the grappling hook gameplay and gamepad controls. Because not only you can hook the enemy, you can boost yourself, slow down time, jump, and so much more. But overtime, I learned to get good and finally experienced that flow state.

Surprisingly, even with this addicting gameplay formula, my favorite part of Sanabi is still the story. Without spoiling anything, you will be confused at first because of the mysteries surrounding Sanabi and Mago are pretty complicated, but once you connect the dots, it will be mind blowing. 

At least mine did, that's for sure. It makes me want to replay the whole game instantly to see all the hints I missed.

Not only mind blowing, Sanabi's story has a lot of heart thanks to its characters. Mind you, Sanabi doesn't have too many characters, since you spend most of your time with a hacker girl named Mari, who's helping you find Sanabi, and her robot companion Mufin.

While Mari might be too talkative to some, I found her character very charming, I really enjoyed her funny personality and antics, and I think the game definitely won't be the same without Mari.

I was too invested in the story of Sanabi, the retired veteran, and Mari. By the end of the game, I was left sobbing my eyes out, heck, I instantly went to write a review, three years after I wrote my previous review.

All of these positive points, combined with the epic soundtracks and the eye catching pixel art, makes the game a complete package worth checking out, even in full price. Scratch that, I insist YOU to try out this game if you love some fast paced action gameplay and heart tugging storytelling.

With that being said, to Wonder Potion a.k.a the developers, I'll be looking forward to your future games! Doesn't matter if it will start as an Early Access product again, I WILL be there!

The game is good, and it's easy to recommend for the price, but it does have an off-putting issue.

The story, the artstyle, the game mechanics, the world-building, and the soundtrack are all top notch. It does however get really tedious at times. It's clearly heavily inspired by Katana Zero, but where Katana Zero effortlessly succeeds in integrating an intriguing plotline with its fast-paced gameplay. This one fails; miserably at times. It felt like the cutscenes and gameplay were constantly interrupting each other, the second you get into the gameplay and are being thrown challenging enemies, you're interrupted by a cutscene twice as long, and when the story gets interesting, you're interrupted with the gameplay. At some point it was hard to enjoy the game cause there was this constant anticipation that the gameplay would come to a grinding halt with a dense cutscene.
I played the speedrun after completing the campaign, and playing it felt leagues better than story mode, the gameplay felt more connected and fluid.
The story is definitely worth experiencing but I don't think it warrants the awful gameplay to cutscene ratio. A lot of it could have been condensed, some of it could have been shown in collectables or records people who are interested could go out of their way to find, having cutscenes between longer sequences of gameplay, etc.

It's good but it would've felt so much better had it put its fast-paced gameplay front and centre, and it seems they could've easily done that.
Has difficulty spikes at times, but worth seeing it to the end.

I have to give this a very reluctant thumbs up.  This is a very good game, but it is certainly not a game that deserves an "Overwhelmingly Positive" tag.  Here's why:

(1) The best part of this game is the story; there is little doubt about that. Though the story is very good, it is absolutely not original, as it is basically an exact copy of a couple very specific movies. Still, the story is worth getting through. I suggest you don't read anything about it and just go through it without any spoilers of any type, even the trailers.

(2) The problem with this "game" is that there is too much emphasis on the story.  You will spend significantly more time watching cut scenes and reading dialogue than actually playing.  That sounds like an exaggeration, but it is 100% true. There is LESS TIME SPENT ON GAMEPLAY THAN ON CUT SCENES. 

(3) The game took some obvious inspiration from Bionic Commando.  Swinging around is fun, but that is basically all you do.  There is little combat here and it is as simplistic as you can possibly get while still calling this a game. 

(4) It way too easy. The challenge of the game is figuring out and becoming adept with the controls.  Once you do that, you fly through the game with ease. 

Some of the reviews compare this to Katana Zero, even saying that it is better than Katana Zero.  I don't think this game is playing in the same league as Katana Zero.  Katana Zero is a far superior game. 

This could have been a legitimate classic if there was more time spent on gameplay and less on cut scenes. This game is a B.  I am not suggesting that you should not play it, as it has its fun parts, but this is really more a movie than a video game.

I'd say this game is great if you just focus on the main parts of the game and just enjoy your time with what you have.
However, if you want to play stuff that isn't included stock... well, your wallet definitely won't be thanking you any time soon.

The music is pretty good, I'd say for every, "Meh, it's okay," you'll have two, "Dang, that's pretty good." But to get that "WOW" feeling, you better cough up some of your precious dollars. This is because the songs that come with the game seem almost specifically designed to be a level or two below the paid content; not enough to really upset you, but just enough to sort of bug you. This will inevitably lead to you buying at least one of the DLC that you simply don't need. All of that knocks off a good chunk of the out-of-ten score.

If you're okay with spending money on what is, admittedly, a decent variety of songs (even if it's an objectively bad deal), then you'll have a really good experience. It's not just the songs that are better; the mapping is, too. The maps in the base-game are alright, but most of them lack a certain level of enjoyment. The DLC maps fix that, in my opinion, bringing the count of really good or enjoyable maps from 1 in 5 to 1 in 3 (or even 1 in 2). The DLC is definitely high quality from what I've seen.

But don't fret over that high price-tag as I once did. There are plenty of sales throughout each year to really enable your addiction to spending, with packs plummeting from around $30 (CAD) to just $7; sometimes, the prices can get even lower than that, so keep an eye out.

Hope this review helped someone. Thanks for reading :)

[b]DJMAX RESPECT V[/b] is one of the most well-crafted rhythm games I’ve ever played. Every penny spent on it is worth the experience. One of the first things that impressed me was how unique and distinct each theme is, with every theme having its own background music when selecting modes. Each chart has its own music video, and if it doesn’t, the game creates an original one, clearly showing the level of care and investment from the developers.

The game is frequently updated, not only adding new songs but also introducing more difficulty levels to older charts. The game features four modes: 4B, 5B, 6B, and 8B. If you want to "get good," you should play every mode, starting from 4B, then progressing to 6B, and so on.

In terms of value, if you're lucky enough to buy the game and its DLCs during a sale, it’s a steal. I was able to get the full game at 80% off.

My only minor complaint is that the game doesn’t have many collaborations with other major rhythm games. While Chunithm and Muse Dash are included, I’d love to see DJMAX RESPECT V collaborate with games like maimai or SDVX and feature more Japanese artists. However, I have to admit that the game already offers a diverse range of music for everyone. I’m not a big fan of K-pop, but DJMAX changed my mind. I got to know more lesser-known Korean artists like TAK, KATOMORI, and XeoN, and I must say, I’m really addicted to their music.

DJMAX RESPECT V truly offers an arcade-like experience at home. [b]Solid 10/10[/b].

My favorite game right now. Better than Risk of Rain 2 and Skul quite possibly will stay my favorite roguelite for a very long time.

Very easy to run on devices, very snappy and intuitive movement, reminds me of cuphead.

Most games like this feel too easy and I end up limiting myself to make it harder. This game, however, is challenging. Each enemy has a different way you need to approach them and level design fits them well. 

Finally, what makes this game so replayable is: 
    -each item can be used in different builds in different ways making you think about item synergy
    -heads in this game can be upgraded a surprising number of times, meaning the developers made walk cycles, unique abilities, and tons and tons of sprites that make each and every different skull and rarity of skull unique
    -when you upgrade your skull there is never a painful change in playstyle. Upgrades always compliment your already developed style of fighting


110/100 definitely recommend

Really good Rogue-like! The skull mechanic is fun and even if some skulls are not as fun, those that are fun make this game really enjoyable. The story is fresh and interesting which is rare in rogue likes. Good difficulty, and when you think you are overpowered, the game is good at skillchecking you.

Skul the protagonist of the game is a pawn with an endless possibilities and builds. 
This is like Terraria where you pick your class at the start (in a manner of choosing a head lol), pick your item with stats (after finishing one room), upgrade your health and damage (earning black crystals after a one whole run).

The game is not restricting you on how you want to play it, like you can go full physical damage with crit + DoT wound debuff, or magic damage with freeze/stun debuff that lets you crowd control mobs and even bosses. I found myself trying so many different ways of playing the game. A standard run of Skul would atleast be around 30 to 45 minutes (not sure if you can reach the latest boss in that time), still depends with your build and also SKILLS.

Probably my most played roguelike ever. I won't say it's entirely balanced in it's mechanics (revenge is op and is practically necessary to beat the harder difficulties/some skulls just feel objectively better than others), but the way the system mechanics work with eachother and the feeling of empowerment once you find a build that hits is a dopamine rush that always hits. This is also a skill based platformer "hack and slash" i guess you could call it, where your skill is just as important as your build and the feeling of improvement learning how to dodge enemy attack patterns is very satisfying. 

A standard run of skul from start to finish will run you about 40 minutes (it saves every room so you can quit and come back whenever). It has a sort of maplestory vibe once you get later into the run, bigger damage numbers and crushing waves of enemies with singular spells, while still having it feel really meaty as you do just from the effort you spent getting to that point. The boss fights are also extremely challenging and it feels good to finally kill one after being stuck on it. I would say this game lands on the harder end of 2D platformers, you really need to master the mechanics to beat the end game bosses. 

Having beaten the hardest difficulty possible and pretty much exhausting all of the content of the game, I got a good 120 hours out of it. Good game. DLC is pretty nice too, just a gives more options for skull/items per run and a new final boss.

Honestly just one of the best games I have ever played. Every single skull feels unique (even if I dislike a few of them) and both the story and world are wonderfully written. If I only had to play one roguelite for the rest of my life, this game would easily be among my top 3 options.

Skul: The Hero Slayer is an entertaining but very challenging roguelike. The game is fairly short, but trying out all the different skulls, their evolutions and the abilities that come with them is fun and will keep you going for a while. Be warned, the game is very difficult! You could try to learn all the enemies' patterns but no matter what, you can be quickly overwhelmed by a horde of 20+ enemies. Instead, your best chance is to find a strong skull (e.g. the ghoul or the minotaurus) and create the perfect build (e.g. focus on physical damage). And if you're getting discouraged, you can always lower the difficulty of the game.

Skul: The Hero Slayer is a breath of fresh air in the roguelite genre, offering a unique twist on the traditional hero's journey. In this game, you play as Skul, a diminutive skeleton warrior fighting against the "heroes" who have invaded the Demon King's castle. The role reversal is both refreshing and entertaining.

The game's standout feature is its innovative skull-swapping mechanic. With over 90 different skulls to collect, each offering distinct playstyles and abilities, the gameplay remains fresh and engaging throughout multiple runs. This system encourages experimentation and adapts to various player preferences, whether you enjoy melee combat, ranged attacks, or magical abilities.

Visually, Skul is a treat. The pixel art style is charming and detailed, bringing the dark fantasy world to life with vibrant colors and fluid animations. The character designs are particularly noteworthy, with each skull transformation showcasing unique and often humorous personalities.

The combat is fast-paced and satisfying, with responsive controls that make navigating through hordes of enemies a joy. The difficulty curve is well-balanced, offering a challenge to seasoned players while remaining accessible to newcomers.

The roguelite elements are well-implemented, with each run feeling different thanks to the variety of skulls, items, and randomized level layouts. The permanent upgrade system provides a sense of progression that keeps you coming back for "just one more run."

While the story isn't the main focus, it offers enough intrigue to keep players invested, with some interesting lore tidbits scattered throughout the game.

One minor criticism is that some skull combinations can feel overpowered, potentially reducing the challenge for experienced players. However, this also allows for some incredibly fun and epic moments.

The Investigations Collection is a fantastic HD port of one solid game and one amazing game that together tells one of the best stories in the entire Ace Attorney series of games. The HD sprite artwork is fantastic, and sets a far better aesthetic standard for the series going forward than the ugly, made-for-handheld 3D models used in Dual Destines and Spirit of Justice. The collections run perfectly on both PC and Steamdeck and I've had no trouble with running them at my monitors native refresh rate and resolution (165hz/1440p). 

As for the games themselves, it's a bit more subjective but the takeaway I'd want to give is this; while the first Investigations game is only *good*, AAI2: Prosecutor's Gambit is a high point for the series not seen since the original trilogy and manages to tell a story that one could argue tops even the original game and Trials and Tribulations. If you are an Ace Attorney fan, it is truly unmissable. I'd say you could get through both games here in around 40 hours (I took my time). 

Really hope they continue down this path and expand on the Investigations format and the series as a whole.

Spending 62 hours to finish both AAI and AAI2, it is a really nice experience. Before playing AAI series, I have played all the other games of Ace Attorney series, and I am absolutely the fan of Ace Attorney. Because I love the rest of games of the series, once AAI can be pre-ordered, I purchased it with no hesitation.

For the game content, the new versions of chibi sprite are really really nice and delicate, which can definitely show the efforts of developer team. Meanwhile, the story and characters are also awesome, and Edgeworth is a better protagonist than Apollo and Athena from my point of view. I also like Shi-Long Lang very much, whose kindness towards his followers attracts me a lot. 

In general, I like AAI series more than Apollo trilogy and Great Ace Attorney series. The story of AAI2 is more interesting than AAI, but AAI is also a great game with lots of turnabouts. I highly recommend people who have finished and like Ace Attorney Phoenix Trilogy to play this investigation series, where you can find a lot of familiar faces, too.

To sum the rest of this review up, these two games are absolutely excellent titles in the Ace Attorney series and a must-play for anyone who enjoyed the other games. Both games mix up the Ace Attorney formula a bit by not actually occurring inside the courtroom (for the most part), but in turn spice up the investigation portion by giving you the ability to actually walk around the crime scene and make deductions yourself. These games are more fast paced than other mainline entries, and I don't ever recall being particularly stuck on any investigation section unlike what happens in a few cases of other Ace Attorney games. I definitely missed the courtroom sections from other games, but you still retain the gameplay of those for the most part, since you will often listen to testimony and issue rebuttals (essentially just cross-examination). Overall, the gameplay is both familiar enough to be fun for any Ace Attorney fan, but different feeling enough to stand out from the rest.

As for story, both games have excellent cases and characters, and I would rate many cases among the best in the entire series. I definitely must say that, in my opinion at least, the second game of the collection is by far stronger in terms of both overall story and character development. I won't spoil anything specific, but the second game spends a lot of time fleshing out Edgeworth as a character as he moves through the events of the game. I'm glad that Capcom released this collection, because before this the second game was never officially translated into English, which is a crying shame. I concede that I never played the fan translation, which I have heard is excellent, but I am nonetheless glad we finally have an official release of the game outside of Japan. 

This collection is absolutely worth playing for Ace Attorney fans both for more Ace Attorney kino in general, but also the great character development we see in classic characters like Edgeworth and Gumshoe. If nothing else in this review convinces you, please play these games so you can witness Gumshoe's finest hours.

A strong duology. With a great art style, colorful new characters, perfect reuse of old and recurring characters, and a good difficulty level - this collection does not disappoint. Easily in the top three ace attorney collections (original PW trilogy and TGAAC being the other two).

Each Edgeworth game could stand on its own, but both being bundled together helps them build off of each other in an enjoyable way. The first game sets up a fairly strong foundation for the second game. The second game uses callbacks and references to the first in a tasteful way.

If I had to nitpick, the second game's case #4 has disruptive pacing for its conclusion that ruins the immersion a tad. FWIW, case #5 cleans that up fairly fast - but it probably could've been handled better. Also, at least currently, there's a few glaring typos in the English localization in game #2 which ruin the immersion.

This is a remaster of a masterpiece. I haven't gotten to Prosecutor's Gambit yet, but the first one has been pretty good so far. The HD sprites and HD backgrounds are impressive, and the chibi sprites are really cute and smoother than your average animation. The UI is nice and user-friendly, and the remade sound and effects in the logic part are very cool. My favourite part of this game is being able to run around and explore, instead of being constrained to looking at one scene like in previous Ace Attorney games or Dual Destinies and Spirit of Justice. It just makes it more immersive, as you play the role of prosecutor/detective exploring the crime scene. Ambassador Alba is still the worst, as always, but in this game, when your health bar runs out, you can immediately load that scene again with full health instead of loading your previous save, which may have been from a long time ago. This saves you a lot of trouble having to save before every cross-examination. The gallery featuring concept art and music is chill and healing. It's not much, but it's great and interesting to visit once in a while. I highly recommend playing this if you have played it before when the graphics were all pixelated.

I have a strange relationship with the Ace Attorney series. On one hand, I do admire the original game and the rest of the two titles in the original trilogy have lots of wonderful moments as well. On the other – I’m not a fan of the ration between adventuring and visual novel storytelling they ever had, very heavily leaning into walls of text and sacrificing gameplay logic over plot twists. That’s the main reason why I stopped playing a couple of hours into The Great Ace Attorney Chronicles as it bored me to tears and I’ve never bothered with the second trilogy either. Which is why I wasn’t sure if I should give Ace Attorney Investigations Collection a go. But after playing the demo and discovering to my relief that this game, as the name implies, is far more into investigative adventuring than the other titles, I gave it a go. And I’m glad I did, as Ace Attorney Investigations: Miles Edgeworth is easily the most enjoyable entry in the series I’ve played. And it will probably be the last one I ever finish.

If you’re unfamiliar with Ace Attorney series, they are titles that combine light adventuring elements and visual novel-style storytelling to bring a rather unique experience of a court room drama. All the rest of the titles in the series are focused almost exclusively on said drama itself, with occasional investigative bits that are entirely linear and extremely primitive. So most of the time is spent on cross-examining someone’s testimonies in court and presenting correct evidence to highlight contradictions in them. Which, as I’ve mentioned already, involves way too much expository talking for my personal liking, as the games feel far more like barely interactive storybooks than adventure games. The original trilogy is still quite fun, especially the first game, but for all the fun twists and funny moments, the further the games went, the more they decided to sacrifice fun adventure elements in favor of guessing correct inputs to move plot forward, even if it’s not always logical. And the plot itself went from over the top and silly, to completely absurd and obnoxiously overcomplicated.

Ace Attorney Investigations breaks away from this approach. Instead of ditching the investigative part, the games (or, well, the first one at least) focuses a lot more on them, providing relatively simple, but genuinely engaging investigative gameplay where you examine the crime scenes, question the witnesses and suspects and connect clues. If you’ve played any of the titles that focus on the similar things, be it Sherlock Holmes titles, Detective Grimoire series or something like L.A. Noire, you know what to expect in general. It’s just somewhat simplified, without (at least usually) holding your hand and still providing the excitement from discovering hidden connections that may change your understanding of the case. Cross-examining testimonies is still present as well, but this time outside of the court setting and is used to bring out new information out of someone who intentionally or accidentally lied, or putting a criminal in a spot where they might reveal who they are to the surrounding crowd of witnesses, making the job of the police easier.

And given that the only game in the collection that I’ve completed is the first one (I’ll talk about the second when we get there),  I have to say that Ace Attorney Investigations: Miles Edgeworth is worth the purchase of the collection alone. It’s not without its flaws, for example the final case lasts way too long and becomes increasingly more absurd and convoluted as it goes. But even that one has strong moments and in general the flow of the game and its story is perfectly delivered. It makes sense, nothing feels too absurd to ruin the gameplay process, cases are interesting (even if they are way too reliant on murder) and vast majority of the logic checks are indeed logical and not of the “guess what the developer was thinking” kind. It’s better enjoyed if you do play the original trilogy of games first as some of the references and returning characters work much better with that knowledge. But it’s not like the original trilogy wasn’t worth playing on its own anyway, so you might as well do it. This isn’t Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective – that adventure game is beyond fantastic, while this one is just very very good. But it’s worth experiencing if you like investigation focused titles or like the Ace Attorney series.

Then I started playing Ace Attorney Investigations 2: Prosecutor’s Gambit and gave up in the middle of the second case. Apart from adding a horrendous new mechanic of “mind chess”, which might be the worst “dialogue battle”-type mini-game I’ve ever experienced in my life, this title just starts with the clown makeup half-applied, and rapidly continues to become a farce by the end of the first case. It’s incredibly stupid, throws several logic-defying “logic checks” at you from the get go, makes several characters that worked so well in the previous game unbearable and then somehow keeps getting even worse as it goes. It also seems to have almost entirely decided to ditch the focus of the investigation in favor of the mind-chess and testimonies, as while investigating still happens, it takes far less time then the talking bits. So after I realized that the game is actively irritating me and doesn’t plan on stopping, I quit it and doubt that I will ever return to finish it.

That said, as I’ve already mentioned, this collection could be not a collection but just Ace Attorney Investigations: Miles Edgeworth and I would’ve still said that it’s worth buying. Maybe not for the full price… but I honestly can’t say that it’s not worth that price, even if you would just play one of two games. It’s a shame that the series are, in general, not really my thing. And reactions from other people to the second game that I couldn’t stomach were quite positive from the fans of the franchise… So I guess, if you’re like me, just like a good adventure game and Ace Attorney never clicked with you before – the first game in the collection might be exactly what you’re looking for. Thankfully, you can try the demo to see for yourself if you want to get it. But I’m glad that I did.

Overall, a fun and entertaining experience to solve cases from Edgeworth's perspective. Definitely play at least games 1 and 2 of the original ace attorney trilogy first though if possible since certain character's character arcs will have already happened during those games, and so going back to them after playing these first might make those titles less enjoyable.

The good:
The characters are generally pretty lovable, with a lot of returning characters getting some form of new spin since they are interacting with Edgeworth instead of Wright. The second game alone makes the collection worth picking up. The first game gives some entertaining origin stories and is needed for context for the second game. The series also does a great job at making these entries feel like their own series and explores the characters appropriately - it stands alone incredibly well from a storytelling perspective even if many characters are reused from the original trilogy. However, definitely play at least the first two games of the original trilogy first to fully appreciate it.

The bad:
Game one is a bit slow and struggles with getting the new gameplay formula working well at times, such as where you'll figure something out and then someone shows up on the scene and requires you to explain the whole thing over to them when you just want to move on. If you can live without achievements, kind of wish I had just used story mode in game 1 for case 3 and the last half of case 5 since they drag way, way too much.

Noita is a fun experience but it honestly at times is utterly brutal. No rouge-like has such a punishing yet rewarding pipeline like Noita. You will reach great heights just as much with great lows and  just like gambling 90% of players quit before they hit big.

[b]Pros;[/b]

- Exploration is vast, lots of secrets/hidden biomes and tools. All equally helpful 
- Rewarding Gameplay loop.
- Modular and vast magic system. 
- Unique art-style and strange world & lore


[b]Cons:[/b]

- Brutal gameplay
- Zero hand-holding
- Late-stage bugs

They never tell you this, but Noita has you playing as the hungriest wizard alive. You can eat most substances that are remotely organic, whether or not you should. Eat enemies, eat their blood, eat the grass, eat oil, you can do it all.

It's also a quality, highly challenging roguelike with a fun and developed magic system deeply ingrained in a fully interactive world that has you tinkering with your wands and their effects to make something strong/fun/insane/all of the above. But we all know that's less important than getting gassy from eating grass like a cow.

One of my favorite games of all time. Today, Cyberpunk 2077 is an incredible experience from start to finish.

The game immerses you in a way that few can, combining its gripping story, breathtaking visuals, and impeccable soundtrack to pull you into the dystopian Night City. There were countless times where I would just stop to look around and take in the gorgeous views.

I found the blend of FPS and RPG elements to be very fun and engaging. Building up V's strength throughout the game was particularly satisfying for me, particularly in how it can interplay with the narrative, even if on the smaller side. Difficulty wise I thought it was pretty balanced overall. It does get on the easier side of things from mid to late game but I don't mind that at all. The game is limited to first person, which I didn't mind after awhile. It's an FPS after all. 
Overall, I loved the high octane, high stakes approach it takes to its combat.

I did not play this game when it first launched, so I have no idea what issues from release still remain. I can however report on the problems I did find regularly:
- Poor LOD Rendering
There were many times, particularly after installing the Phantom Liberty DLC, where the game's engine struggled a lot with loading LODs properly. I mainly noticed it with the NPCs and vehicles, especially when driving, where they would load at very low detail until you're like a few steps away. Rarely when driving, the road can just unload for some reason and become invisible for a couple seconds, which can really screw with you. This is pretty uncommon though.
- Low Traffic Density While Driving
When you're not driving around the city, the traffic is pretty normal. However, once you start going at high speeds on the road, traffic seems to diminish significantly. This does create an uncanny result considering its supposed to be a mega city. It seems the game does this to further save on resources, but it is still somewhat distracting how little traffic there can be.
- Vehicle Summoning
The game allows you to call your vehicle, and it will drive itself to you. Even to this day, the menu for this still says the feature is in beta. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any plans to properly finish it. Now, I bring this up because a lot of the time, the place that it chooses to spawn your car is..not great. Sometimes it will spawn on another road that's like a block away, and other times it spawns it in other vehicles. But on occasion, the car may straight up spawn in the air, where you can watch it gracefully tumble all the way to the ground. Other than traditional fast travel, cars and motorcycles are the de facto way to get around Night City, so a feature like this should probably have had more time in the oven.

Despite those recurring issues I had, they are nowhere near game breaking. They only hurt the already amazing immersion a bit. I did not really experience any crashes before installing mods, so those issues seem to be gone. In all, I definitely think the game is in a good place now. If you were thinking about getting Cyberpunk for yourself, I highly recommend it.

High-quality, in-depth non-party Action RPG (ARPG). All the RPG elements you'd expect, fully voiced, great post-release maintenance/commitment and in a truly interesting non-fanstasy setting. The mechanics don't really mirror Cyberpunk 2020 or Cyberpunk: RED TTRPGs; while unfortunate, the mechanics in this game are solid.

And best of all, the game very moddable with a vibrant, engaged, and productive mod community.

Only disappointing aspect was that it has no 3rd person. You cannot see the character of the story, you cannot see their cool moves and action. Rather it's like you, the player at the computer, is there rather than the character of the story. And it wasn't immediately apparent how this weakens the whole experience.

But other than that there are only two minor points of weakness, both addressable in the mature product:
1. Boss fights assume certain style of play--the dev's preference. This is solvable by mods.
2. CDPR having their favorite story ending and putting weak effort into other endings because you should have thought like the devs and writers to get the best endgame experience [see Witcher 3]. This is solvable by research and then playing the fleshed out single ending CDPR envisioned.

Everything else is top notch, engaging, and fun. Has all the RPG elements you'd expect and good quests, decent story lines. DLC is lacking, but they did release one at least--it's also very decent; almost more interesting than the main storyline [again, see Witcher 3].

Worth a buy, especially on sale if you are irritated by the detractors--full price, imo, if you are not! Have fun, choom!
